fields.headline: Cascarino never eligible for Irish
fields.trailText: Tony Cascarino, who made a record 88 appearances for the Republic of Ireland, does not hold an Irish passport and has never been eligible to play for the country.
fields.body:
Tony Cascarino, who made a record 88 appearances for the Republic of Ireland, does not hold an Irish passport and has never been eligible to play for the country.

Cascarino makes the confession to Dublin's Sunday Independent, who have serialisation rights to his forthcoming autobiography, Full Time: The Secret Life of Tony Cascarino. A lengthy extract from the book appears in next week's Observer Sport Monthly magazine.

The man who was known as 'Tony Goal' at the height of his up-and-down career - he played for Chelsea, Aston Villa, Celtic, Marseille and Nancy - says: 'I didn't qualify for Ireland. I was a fraud. A fake Irishman.'

The Football Association of Ireland president, Bernard O'Byrne, said his executive would discuss the revelations this week, and while they would consider taking away Cascarino's caps, such a course of action was unlikely. Three of Cascarino's 'Anglo' team-mates, Steve Staunton, Andy Townsend and Niall Quinn, knew about Cascarino's secret for the past four years after the striker quit international football, according to the Dublin report.

Cascarino admits that despite being turned down for an Irish passport in 1985, after he had already made three appearances in the green shirt, he carried on representing Ireland regardless. During a 13-year international career, the Kent-born former hairdresser appeared in World Cups and European Championships. He played against England three times.

Cascarino genuinely believed an Irish maternal grandfather, Michael O'Malley, from Westport, qualified him to play for Ireland when he was first selected. He discovered that O'Malley was not a blood relative only in 1986. His mother discovered only on her father's deathbed that she was not his natural daughter.

Cascarino's confession is the latest in a string of controversies about the eligibility of players in several sports. It will reopen the debate about whether sports governing bodies are sufficiently rigorous in checking players' backgrounds.

In the book, Cascarino relates how he was first called up by Ireland in 1985 when he was at Gillingham. Having always thought his maternal grandfather was Irish, he believed he was eligible under the 'one grandparent' rule.

Cascarino submitted 'evidence' of his Irish antecedents to the Irish embassy in London and began playing international football. He had played against Switzerland, Russia and Denmark before he heard back from the embassy. 'Finally, the envelope arrived and they were all there, all my mother's documents - and a letter saying it had been declined.

'It seemed odd but I didn't follow it up. I didn't need to. I had won three international caps. And for the next 11 years, I continued playing for Ireland with my British passport.'

Throughout Cascarino's international career, his mother knew that his supposed Irish grandfather was not her real father and therefore was not a blood relative, but she said nothing. She revealed the truth to her son only when he retired from international football.

fields.headline: Thome alone for first goal
fields.trailText: More misery for keeper Kirkland and unlucky Coventry.
fields.byline: John Wardle at The Stadium of Light
fields.body:
Chris Kirkland, the Coventry keeper controversially sent off at Chelsea last week, was again left aggrieved by a refereeing decision which effectively settled the outcome of an untidy game here.

The 19-year-old departed in tears after an unfortunate red card at Stamford Bridge, while yesterday his reaction to Emerson Thome's winning goal, when he claimed to have been impeded, earned him a yellow.

It's quite a collection for somebody who has played only three Premiership matches, but his manager, Gordon Strachan, is adamant that Kirkland deserved neither of them.

Strachan said: 'People might think he's a bit petulant, but he's been very unlucky. He made the referee aware he was being blocked at set pieces, and he said he would look out for him at corners.

'Then Chris asked why he didn't see him being obstructed when they scored and the ref told him he missed it. He looked for protection and the ref wasn't watching. That can upset players.'

Strachan is a manager who is also easily upset, but even his Sunderland counterpart accepted City had some justification for being annoyed when an offside flag ruled out a goal from Craig Bellamy in the 31st minute.

Peter Reid admitted: 'I thought Bellamy was behind our defenders. We got away with that one and, if I was Gordon, I would feel a bit hard done by. They deserved something out of the game.'

Reid's words represent a fair assessment because here were two teams prepared to sacrifice style and enterprise for workrate and commitment.

Opportunities were rare, and once Thome's header met Arca's corner with impressive power and direction for his first Sunderland goal, Coventry made little headway against a defence who have not conceded in the past four games. Kevin Phillips's goals may not be as plentiful as last season, but the defiance of Thome is proving adequate compensation.

Reid said: 'It wasn't pretty, but we looked very solid and resilient. We know we are not fluent at the moment, yet it's a good sign when you win matches when you're not playing well.'

Strachan added: 'My players were embarrassed seven days ago; today, the disappointment is huge. It was a brave performance with all the things I look for from my side. We've done our part, but circumstances dictated the outcome.'

fields.headline: Teddy strikes again
fields.trailText: Teddy hits a hat-trick as United bounce back.
fields.body:
At a club where the star player's preferred choice of undergarment can dominate the national psyche, talk of crisis and disaster can come cheap. If the wheels are in danger of coming off at Manchester United, as Sir Alex Ferguson claimed following European defeat in midweek, the rest of the Premiership can pack up for summer now.

Admittedly, it took the ghost of the much-maligned and unlamented Massimo Taibi to lift a perfunctory first-half United display.

Thirteen months ago, Paul Jones watched the Italian keeper earn his 'Blind Venetian' moniker as he allowed a speculative Matt Le Tissier strike through his grasp in a 3-3 draw with the Saints. Yesterday, at the same East Stand end, Jones presented Andy Cole with an almost carbon copy goal to commence the rout.

That error negated a bright opening by the visitors and, allied with a remarkable 10-minute hat-trick by the irrepressible Teddy Sheringham - the first of his United career - assured Southampton of a long and painful afternoon.

Sheringham, 34, has been the one unqualified success of an inconsistent opening quarter to the season by the champions. Buoyed by a new one-year contract and with talks pending over a one-year extension, he has now scored 11 times this season, already eclipsing last season's production.

'He's been fantastic,' said Ferguson. 'He has started the season well and probably signing the contract has given him the assurance about being wanted here. He made the point about not being the number-one choice the last couple of years. I don't see why we wouldn't do the same again with another contract.

'The second-half performance didn't look on the horizon in the first, but it was a satisfying performance coming in a week where there was a lot of disappointment around the place. We don't like losing games but the great thing about these people's characters is they can prove that.'

Sheringham's sublime demonstration of finishing would come later. First, came the ridiculous. Cole spun well, 20 yards from goal, in the 10th minute and his shot possessed more spin and velocity than Le Tissier's notorious effort but should still have presented no problem to Jones who, instead, lurched forward and smoth ered the ball before allowing it to worm through his body and over the line.

As déjà vu goes, it was like watching a road traffic accident unfurl in slow motion or, as his tight-lipped manager Glenn Hoddle grimaced after the game: 'I can only imagine he took his eye off the ball.'

That was a quality the United defence, showing two personnel and one positional change from midweek defeat at Anderlecht, also displayed in abundance as Southampton enjoyed the better of first-half possession and the hosts struggled to settle into an attacking rhythm.

Hassan Kachloul made much of the space afforded him, twice trying his luck from long range, Draper likewise, while Fabien Barthez entered the spirit of goalkeeper giving by striking a clearance against the back of Jo Tessem, gratefully clutching the rebound to his chest.

Sheringham hopelessly miskicked in front of goal and headed wide two pinpoint crosses from David Beckham - he of the great, nationally televised, underwear debate - before an injury-time goal, which, while undeserved, was the signal for the unrelenting second-half rout.

After Sheringham had swung a shot across goal, Southampton failed to clear the danger and the ball came back to Sheringham just inside the Saints area, presenting him with the opportunity to produce a fabulous left-foot chip over Jones.

It soon became apparent that even a sub-par United still require no second invitation to go in for the kill once opponents have shown their vulnerability and the second goal removed any element of competition from the game.

On the 50th minute, Sheringham struck again at the end of a flowing, right-wing move, Paul Scholes wide to Beckham and his drag-back presenting the England man with a right-foot finish from 15 yards.

Five minutes on, and a stunning hat-trick was complete with Nicky Butt floating into the area, Cole holding up the ball and Sheringham continuing what was rapidly becoming an afternoon of target practice from a dozen yards.

Giggs thundered a shot against the underside of the bar, Beckham shaved it with a 20-yard free-kick before Cole completed his afternoon's work with a simple close-range header after Scholes had helped on a 73rd-minute Beckham corner.

There was also the chance for Jones to atone for previous misdemeanours via two fabulous late saves from United substitute Dwight Yorke.

'The emergency signs are flashing,' Ferguson had said before the game. They are, but as far as domestic football is concerned, they flash not for United but for the pretenders to their crown.

fields.headline: Rougier rains on Oxford's parade
fields.trailText: Thames Valley royal show edged by the favourites.
fields.byline: Nicholas Harling at the Madejski Stadium
fields.body:
At the respective ends of the rainbow that curled high over the stadium after this tumultuous match in torrential rain, there was potential gold for Reading but a growing pile of dust for Oxford United. As Reading regained the Second Division leadership with two goals in the last 12 minutes from their substitute, Tony Rougier, Oxford, stranded at the foot of the table, reflected on the likelihood of two divisions separating them from their neighbours next autumn.

Yet seldom have a club, described beforehand as 'an absolute shambles' by caretaker chief Mike Ford, come so close to managing a victory that would have ranked as the upset of the season. Without a manager since Denis Smith was forced upstairs, or a point now from nine away games, Oxford are in disarray on and off the pitch. Yet their neat passing, revolving around the industrious Matty Murphy, belied their plight.

They started anxiously. Within five minutes Lee Hodges had sent in Jamie Cureton to bang a shot against the advancing Richard Knight and to hit an upright from the rebound. Cureton made a dreadful hash of John Richardson's woeful back pass two minutes later. Reading's first goal came after 28 minutes. When Cureton's drive was blocked, Lee Jarman brought down Darren Caskey, who stroked home the penalty without fuss. Oxford had not threatened a goal until their former goalkeeper, Phil Whitehead, fell on to the by-line as he arched backwards going for Ricky Newman's headed back-pass. As the ball squirmed from his grasp, Derek Lilley overcame his disbelief to slide it into the gaping net.

Murphy swung and missed at the chance that could have given Oxford the lead before Reading punished them. Their erratic shooting had not troubled Knight before he dropped a routine 68th- minute attempt from Caskey. Cureton smashed in a loose ball to herald a goal spree.

Within a minute Oxford had equalised. Peter Fear's free-kick was driven back by Jarman and turned into his own net by Adi Viveash. In the 72nd minute Oxford did score a goal from the coaching manual when Richardson glanced in Fear's corner. Oxford's jubilant supporters sensed the shock of all shocks. But their team could not cling on, thanks to Alan Pardew's inspired substitution. He sent on Rougier, who obliged by driving in Hodges's corner which fell conveniently for him at the far post.

Not content with his first goal for the club, the Trinidadian was no less clinical from Jim McIntyre's subsequent deep cross. The ball bounced tamely clear from Andy Linighan's outstretched leg and in a cloud of spray Rougier buried the wayward clearance to send Oxford away sodden and sad.

fields.headline: Wearing nothing but Channel No 5
fields.standfirst: Dawn Airey has been vilified as the sex-obsessed female who put bums and boobs all over British television screens. Her driving ambition is expected to propel her to even greater power.
fields.trailText: Dawn Airey has been vilified as the sex-obsessed female who put bums and boobs all over British television screens. Her driving ambition is expected to propel her to even greater power. By Ben Summerskill.
fields.body:
Yesterday morning's breakfast will not have been a cheery occasion in the Knightsbridge home of Daily Mail editor-in-chief Paul Dacre. A highly personal campaign by his papers to discredit one of British television's high-fliers, Dawn Airey of Channel 5, had just backfired. Late on Friday afternoon, the station announced that Airey was being promoted to become Channel 5's chief executive. The pornographer-in-chief was being put in charge of the brothel.

It is a blunt repudiation of the Mail 's highly personal and sometimes vindictive campaign against 39-year-old Airey. It reminds us once again that the moral majoritarians who control the paper, and those who identify with them, have less grip upon the heartlands of Britain than they like to think.

Just four months ago, the Mail unleashed a campaign of vilification against Channel 5 for broadcasting Naked Jungle , a gameshow hosted by middle-aged presenter Keith Chegwin with no clothes on. Billed cheekily by Airey as an 'exploration of naturism', the programme was remarkable more for the startling slightness of Chegwin's member than any sauciness from the contestants, who also undressed.

The Mail 's blitzkrieg on the show monickered the broadcasters Channel Filth. But six weeks later the Broadcasting Standards Commission conceded that they had received just seven complaints from members of the public. 'It just did not appear to have upset people and generated a tiny response,' said then BSC chairman Lord Holme.

If only Channel 5's detractors could see it, it was a classic demonstration of the marketing nous that has made the station a success. After its shaky launch in the spring of 1997 when half its new viewers saw screens of white snow, it now reaches 84 per cent of British house holds, and looks set to challenge Channel 4's market share.

'We never quite understand why people happily make all the fuss, but we're very grateful,' said a senior source at the station's chic, but modest, central London head office. 'All we have to do is lob a gentle firecracker. The tabloid newspapers go bonkers. Hardly anything ever gets put in a written press release, so no one can say we misled them. And we get publicity we just couldn't buy. Millions tune in to see our so-called pornography. If 5 per cent of them stay behind for some other programme we're laughing all the way to the bank.'

Airey gave a personal demonstration of exactly this tactic when she appeared on Question Time in March this year. Innocently observing that her station's celebrated 'adult output' was being broadcast at exactly the same time as the BBC1 programme, she caused two million viewers to switch over.

But what BBC1's disloyal audience would have seen is hardly pornography at all. It is the gentle smut that has been available on adult cable channels across Europe and America for years. If anyone at Channel 5 sits glued to the screen previewing its bought-in late night films, they are extremely unlikely to go blind before its soft-focus footage of boobies and bottoms.

It exemplifies the channel under Airey and her team. The ethos extends not just to late-night films, but to gentle middlebrow broadcasting. Daytime sofa chat hosted by Gloria Hunniford, the competition Fort Boyard fronted by Melinda Messenger and her famous embonpoint , and, of course, Chegwin. The five nights-a-week soap Family Affairs - which had its own Marchioness-style disaster - attracts three million viewers a week.

Channel 5's high water mark so far was BBC and ITV's notorious 'Black Wednesday' on 8 September 1999. Screening England's crucial Euro 2000 qualifier against Poland in Warsaw, the station achieved an audience of 5.6 million.

Current audience share, touching 6 per cent of total TV viewing after just four years on air, demonstrates that many mid-market viewers are rather more astute than Britain's legion of snooty TV critics.

While it remains painfully obvious that most Channel 5 programmes are low budget, TV consumers have noticed that this makes them no different from much of the output now also shown on ITV, Channel 4 and BBC1.

Last Sunday, with the benefit of the blockbuster film Mrs Doubtfire , audience share rose to 9.2 per cent. That is where Airey comes in. Her predecessor David Elstein, edged out last week with a £4 million share option sweetener, was committed to the 'films, football and fucking' agenda once attributed to Airey herself.

However, a colleague of Airey's explained yesterday: 'Dawn does believe that you can grow the entire audience. Some of that will come down to budget and programme quality, but there is a recognition that lifestyle shows and light, but not pretentious, documentaries have a role to play in building audience profile.

'You don't always have to have the highest audience to guarantee the highest ad yields if you start picking up ABC1s, even when they're promiscuous viewers. Dawn knows that Channel 5 has no constituency which sits down and turns it on automatically, a sort of lethargy which still benefits the BBC and ITV. We have to win them over almost every time. She wants C5 to become more sticky, so people hang around.'

The channel has already launched a series of innocent 'smily' adverts to emphasise its general appeal to family audiences and the late-night boobies are not quite as prevalent as they were. However, there is still likely to be 'creative tension' with Richard Eyre, the devoutly Christian director of strategy for RTL, Channel 5's main shareholder. Eyre, once improbably reported to speak in tongues at a south London Baptist church, insists: 'I would never interfere in programme content on the basis of my personal beliefs.'

Airey's determination is not in doubt. Anyone who has observed her in the gym - redfaced and awash with sweat - will gather that she is a woman who takes almost everything very seriously. Indeed.

She has supreme self-belief. Last year, she trained at Harvard Business School while continuing to run her fledgling channel. Her personal critics have often apparently been motivated by the unpleasant envy habitual when a woman in Britain does well -she must be unbalanced, or sex-starved or, as novelist Will Self chose to hint in a newspaper interview, lesbian.

But Airey gives the impression of appearing not to care. Her matey bonhomie, which makes Mo Mowlam look restrained, is widely admired. And her Cambridge background, just like her predecessor's double-first, is kept well-disguised. What you see, her friends insist, is what you get. Nobody who has studied her previous form - links with Drop The Dead Donkey , Don't Forget Your Toothbrush and The Big Breakfast - can be under any illusion as to the sort of broadcasting she champions. She will also seek to use an increased budget to boost sports coverage.

A BBC source has suggested that it might have been an approach from Greg Dyke - a firm admirer - that precipitated C5's decision to promote Airey. But in future she will look over-qualified to be a mere programme controller. The chief executive's job at a merged ITV, expected within the next three years, almost certainly beckons.

And while the critics continue to carp at Channel 5, it will still be less from censoriousness than old-fashioned snobbishness. Paul Dacre might be disgusted by its 'Carry On Don't Lose Your Bra' public persona, tempered by a dark touch of Joe Orton - this autumn's scheduling highlights include a weekly post-mortem show - and promoted with the irreverence of St Trinians mischiefmakers. But it all touches a seam in the British psyche. Under Airey, this knowing televisual Bacchanalia is unlikely to fizzle out.

Billed cheekily by Airey as an 'exploration of naturism', the programme was remarkable more for the startling slightness of Chegwin's member than any sauciness from the contestants, who also undressed. The Mail 's blitzkrieg on the show monickered the broadcasters Channel Filth. But six weeks later the Broadcasting Standards Commission conceded that they had received just seven complaints from members of the public. 'It just did not appear to have upset people and generated a tiny response,' said then BSC chairman Lord Holme. If only Channel 5's detractors could see it, it was a classic demonstration of the marketing nous that has made the station a success. After its shaky launch in the spring of 1997 when half its new viewers saw screens of white snow, it now reaches 84 per cent of British house holds, and looks set to challenge Channel 4's market share. 'We never quite understand why people happily make all the fuss, but we're very grateful,' said a senior source at the station's chic, but modest, central London head office. 'All we have to do is lob a gentle firecracker. The tabloid newspapers go bonkers. Hardly anything ever gets put in a written press release, so no one can say we misled them. And we get publicity we just couldn't buy. Millions tune in to see our so-called pornography. If 5 per cent of them stay behind for some other programme we're laughing all the way to the bank.' Airey gave a personal demonstration of exactly this tactic when she appeared on Question Time in March this year. Innocently observing that her station's celebrated 'adult output' was being broadcast at exactly the same time as the BBC1 programme, she caused two million viewers to switch over. But what BBC1's disloyal audience would have seen is hardly pornography at all. It is the gentle smut that has been available on adult cable channels across Europe and America for years. If anyone at Channel 5 sits glued to the screen previewing its bought-in late night films, they are extremely unlikely to go blind before its soft-focus footage of boobies and bottoms. It exemplifies the channel under Airey and her team. The ethos extends not just to late-night films, but to gentle middlebrow broadcasting. Daytime sofa chat hosted by Gloria Hunniford, the competition Fort Boyard fronted by Melinda Messenger and her famous embonpoint , and, of course, Chegwin. The five nights-a-week soap Family Affairs - which had its own Marchioness-style disaster - attracts three million viewers a week. Channel 5's high water mark so far was BBC and ITV's notorious 'Black Wednesday' on 8 September 1999. Screening England's crucial Euro 2000 qualifier against Poland in Warsaw, the station achieved an audience of 5.6 million. Current audience share, touching 6 per cent of total TV viewing after just four years on air, demonstrates that many mid-market viewers are rather more astute than Britain's legion of snooty TV critics. While it remains painfully obvious that most Channel 5 programmes are low budget, TV consumers have noticed that this makes them no different from much of the output now also shown on ITV, Channel 4 and BBC1. Last Sunday, with the benefit of the blockbuster film Mrs Doubtfire , audience share rose to 9.2 per cent. That is where Airey comes in. Her predecessor David Elstein, edged out last week with a £4 million share option sweetener, was committed to the 'films, football and fucking' agenda once attributed to Airey herself. However, a colleague of Airey's explained yesterday: 'Dawn does believe that you can grow the entire audience. Some of that will come down to budget and programme quality, but there is a recognition that lifestyle shows and light, but not pretentious, documentaries have a role to play in building audience profile. 'You don't always have to have the highest audience to guarantee the highest ad yields if you start picking up ABC1s, even when they're promiscuous viewers. Dawn knows that Channel 5 has no constituency which sits down and turns it on automatically, a sort of lethargy which still benefits the BBC and ITV. We have to win them over almost every time. She wants C5 to become more sticky, so people hang around.' The channel has already launched a series of innocent 'smily' adverts to emphasise its general appeal to family audiences and the late-night boobies are not quite as prevalent as they were. However, there is still likely to be 'creative tension' with Richard Eyre, the devoutly Christian director of strategy for RTL, Channel 5's main shareholder. Eyre, once improbably reported to speak in tongues at a south London Baptist church, insists: 'I would never interfere in programme content on the basis of my personal beliefs.' Airey's determination is not in doubt. Anyone who has observed her in the gym - redfaced and awash with sweat - will gather that she is a woman who takes almost everything very seriously. Indeed. She has supreme self-belief. Last year, she trained at Harvard Business School while continuing to run her fledgling channel. Her personal critics have often apparently been motivated by the unpleasant envy habitual when a woman in Britain does well -she must be unbalanced, or sex-starved or, as novelist Will Self chose to hint in a newspaper interview, lesbian. But Airey gives the impression of appearing not to care. Her matey bonhomie, which makes Mo Mowlam look restrained, is widely admired. And her Cambridge background, just like her predecessor's double-first, is kept well-disguised. What you see, her friends insist, is what you get. Nobody who has studied her previous form - links with Drop The Dead Donkey , Don't Forget Your Toothbrush and The Big Breakfast - can be under any illusion as to the sort of broadcasting she champions. She will also seek to use an increased budget to boost sports coverage. A BBC source has suggested that it might have been an approach from Greg Dyke - a firm admirer - that precipitated C5's decision to promote Airey. But in future she will look over-qualified to be a mere programme controller. The chief executive's job at a merged ITV, expected within the next three years, almost certainly beckons. And while the critics continue to carp at Channel 5, it will still be less from censoriousness than old-fashioned snobbishness. Paul Dacre might be disgusted by its 'Carry On Don't Lose Your Bra' public persona, tempered by a dark touch of Joe Orton - this autumn's scheduling highlights include a weekly post-mortem show - and promoted with the irreverence of St Trinians mischiefmakers. But it all touches a seam in the British psyche. Under Airey, this knowing televisual Bacchanalia is unlikely to fizzle out. ben.summerskill@observer.co.uk

webTitle: Pearce stars in old boys' show

fields.headline: Pearce stars in old boys' show
fields.trailText: Pearce and Winterburn lift Hammers and give youth an object lesson.
fields.body:
A rare goal from Frederic Kanoute gave West Ham their first home win of the season, lifting them clear of the Premiership's relegation places and dragging Newcastle out of the top six.

But a match that had been billed as a potential goal feast from the future of English football will be remembered more for the enduring qualities of some former England internationals, who make a mockery of sell-by-dates.

Newcastle chucked everything at West Ham for the 17 minutes remaining after Kanoute's decisive strike, but they never ever looked like breaking the spirit of 38-year-old Stuart Pearce at the heart of the West Ham defence.

Pearce, discarded on a free transfer from Newcastle 14 months ago, was matched in enthusiasm, ability and effort by his team-mate Nigel Winterburn, 36, a summer cast off from Arsenal.

At the other end, there was Robert Lee, a 34-year-old demoted from the first team squad by former Newcastle manager Ruud Gullit. He played his first game as a sweeper yesterday and reminded current Newcastle manager Bobby Robson of the great Franz Beckenbauer.

Pearce stood out, however, and his manager, Harry Redknapp, said: 'I sometimes feel I don't need to coach the kids here - I could just say look at Stuart Pearce. He can go on for the rest of this season and the next if he avoids injury. He has got the body of a 20-year-old, he has every muscle there, it's quite impressive.'

One can indulge Redknapp's enthusiasm on a day when the luck finally ran his way, for Newcastle will play a lot worse and win games this season. 'It's a depressing result, but not a depressing performance,' Robson said. 'We have lost three games 1-0 this season and have not deserved to lose them.'

Though neither team has been on top of their game recently, the omens for goalmouth action were good if only because injuries had stretched both sides' defences to the limit. So the crowd sat back and waited for the goals to flow. And they waited, waited and waited. There was plenty of attacking intent, but not a shot on target until the 26th minute.

And what a shot it was. The mesmerising Joe Cole clipped a cross to the edge of the area and Frank Lampard struck a venomous first-time scissors volley that Shay Given tipped over the bar with an equally impressive save.

The action was generally too fast and frantic for the skills of players such as Cole and Kieron Dyer to really take a hold of the game. Cole began to have more of an influence at the start of the second half so it was a shame that Tresor Lomana Lua-Lua marked his first start for Newcastle by effectively kicking him out of the game.

Davor Suker then laid on Kanoute's goal with a clever flick and the Frenchman turned and shot in one movement to beat Given. Newcastle had chances late on and they will argue they deserved more, but West Ham were just the more clinical going forward and probability said that they had to win at home sometime.

webTitle: Comment: TV is not bad for children

fields.headline: TV is not bad for children - official
fields.standfirst: Well, almost official, as results of a unique study show that people not programmes affect behaviour.
fields.trailText: Well, almost official, as results of a unique study show that people not programmes affect behaviour, writes Tony Charlton.
fields.body:
Television is bad for us. It corrodes the moral fabric of society and corrupts our children with relentless images of violence. Well, that's what the proponents of increased television regulation - politicians, social campaigners and certain elements of the media- would like us to believe.

Yet events on one of the world's most remote inhabited islands tell a different and fascinating story, one which is less palatable to those who seek an convenient scapegoat for the ills of modern society.

Five years ago, television arrived on St Helena, in the South Atlantic. Previously, the inhabitants of this isolated British sovereignty, to which Napoleon Bonaparte was exiled, had no access to broadcast television. Amid the excitement of its arrival, there was concern that exposure to television would have a detrimental impact on the island's children, previously shown to be among the best behaved in the world.

This event provided researchers with a rare opportunity to examine the effects of television in a real-life setting both before and after its arrival. Previous research had mostly relied on studies in artificial laboratory conditions. Findings have been contradictory, with some studies providing conclusive evidence of links between television viewing and antisocial behaviour, others claiming beneficial effects and some denying any links at all. What all these studies had in common was that they lacked real life. The opportunity to gather pre- and post-TV-watching data using a whole population (rather than samples) of children was gratefully seized by myself and colleagues; here was a real chance toput television on trial.

The St Helena research project began collecting data two years before television arrived, chiefly by observing children in classrooms and school playgrounds. Other information came from teachers and pupils themselves. These data showed children to be hard working and very well behaved. After television became available, most of the same measures were repeated in each of the next five years. Additionally, children's viewing was sampled and a content analysis of the programmes watched, indicating the amount of violence seen, was also undertaken. And in the post-TV phase, comparisons were made between viewers' and non-viewers' behaviour. Links were also investigated between children's behaviour and the levels of violence they saw.

The project's latest findings, using observations of children's playground behaviour, are being presented today at the international meeting on children's film and media education in Varise, Italy. Contrary to most other research, they show - after five years of viewing - that television does not unequivocally or inevitably influence children's social behaviour in adverse ways. These results are entirely consonant with other findings from the project over the past four years.

One feasible explanation for this finding came from a recorded group discussion with older students. They concluded it was difficult to engage in anti-social acts on the island 'because everyone watches you... everyone knows you... you've just got to behave'. Seemingly, family and community social controls were more persuasive in shaping children's behaviour than exposure to television. There is a ring of truth about this reasoning, as most parents will know.

In a similar vein, research elsewhere has shown that high levels of social control and strong informal support networks are influential in shaping behaviour. Adults would be involved in both. However, the influence of significant adults is seldom considered when causes of anti-social behaviour are sought. While it hurts to admit that children's flawed behaviour is often shaped by us, a denial of this only masks untoward consequences of considerable changes in our lives.

For instance, support networks are less conspicuous now than a generation ago. Families, neighbourhoods and communities have lost much of their unity and influence Many homes are now headed by single parents. Marriages have declined, divorce rates have risen and kinship links have weakened.

Levels of care, compassion and togetherness have dwindled in many neighbourhoods and communities. Urban apathy is widespread and children often grow up away from the watchful eyes of close relatives. Increasingly, both parents are away from home during workday hours. And, all too easily, young family members may be left unsupervised in the home and neighbourhood.

These changes have given many youngsters unlimited opportunities to learn anti-social traits from their unsupervised TV viewing, as well as freely practise them without fear of detection, let alone retribution.

Cases of vandalism, theft, assaults and public-order offences have become commonplace in many of our towns and cities, yet reproaching television succeeds only in deflecting attention from the actual source of our concerns. Quite simply, it is often the case (within and outside homes) that there are too few adults around who are willing and able to supervise and check youngsters' (and others') behaviour satisfactorily.

In St Helena, what we are witnessing is how healthy family, neighbourhood and community forces can combine effectively in shaping children's behaviour. Although young viewers can learn anti-social behaviour from television, opportunities to practise it are limited by the presence of watchful eyes.

There are lessons to be learned from St Helena. Nevertheless, the dilemma facing most westernised communities is more about how to revive and then utilise these influential forces rather than about current arguments on watersheds and regulatory controls.

 Professor Tony Charlton is a psycologist at the Centre for Behaviour Studies in Cheltenham, and part of the St Helena research team.

webTitle: Losses double at Prince's TV firm

fields.headline: Losses double at Prince's TV firm
fields.standfirst: MP raises tax query as Edward's production company posts a deficit for eighth successive year.
fields.trailText: MP raises tax query as Edward's production company posts a deficit for eighth successive year, writes Ben Summerskill.
fields.body:
Prince Edward's hapless TV career will be in the spotlight again this week as his company prepares to announce substantial losses for the eighth year running. Ardent Productions will disclose that its annual operating losses almost doubled, from £122,000 in 1998 to £222,000 last year.

Ardent, set up by the Prince in 1993, has now posted cumulative losses of £1.9 million. The firm has paid no corporation tax since Edward launched it with the promise that it would become 'one of the top 12' British TV production houses by 2000.

The company's principal current project is a documentary about the sex lives of young British expatriates. X-Pats will include scenes of a financial trader who uses transvestite prostitutes, according to a source at Channel 5, which commissioned it. Ardent is also working on interview programmes featuring veteran singers.

Last year, the Prince provoked outrage by telling the New York Times that the British 'hate anyone who succeeds'. Americans responded to his programme proposals, he claimed, 'like a breath of fresh air'.

John Whiting, a partner at the leading accountants, PricewaterhouseCoopers, said yesterday: 'In normal circumstances, if a firm showed losses for six years, that would be an automatic trigger point for [the Inland Revenue] asking questions about why they are losing money. They will want to be satisfied that there is genuinely a loss.'

Norman Baker, the Liberal Democrat MP for Lewes, said: 'It is very curious when any company appears to make losses indefinitely.' He too would expect the Revenue to check on such a company.

Ardent pays £50,000 a year in rent to another firm controlled by Edward for offices at Bagshot Park, the Surrey seat of the Prince and his wife, the Countess of Wessex.

Local estate agents Chancellor & Sons said offices were available more cheaply nearby. 'A broad price guide would be £10 a square foot, with very reasonable property available for £15,' said the firm's Max Scott. Rent for an ample office for 12 staff could be between £7,500 and £11,250 a year, rather than the £50,000 which Ardent can currently offset against future tax liabilities.

There is, no doubt, an entirely innocent explanation, however Ardent chairman Malcolm Cockren was unavailable to comment.

It emerged earlier this year that almost £2 million of public money has been spent on refurbishing Bagshot Park since Edward moved in in 1997. The Ministry of Defence, its former owner, funded the repairs after the Prince signed a 50-year lease to rent the property from the Crown Estate. Buckingham Palace insisted the repairs would have been carried out at public expense regardless of who lived in the property, built by Queen Victoria for her third son, Arthur, Duke of Connaught.

The London-based building firm C J Sims, which did the refurbishment, went into receivership earlier this year. It said one of its outstanding payments was £600,000 owed by the Prince.

Ardent's new accounts, due to be filed at Companies House by Tuesday, will say its turnover was £326,210 last year, down from £424,773, and that its distribution company, Ardent International Sales, made a loss of £28,731.

Shareholders, who each provided up to £200,000 in funding when the company was founded, included the Sultan of Brunei and Sir Tom Farmer, the chairman of the Kwik-Fit car exhaust centres. Farmer insisted last summer that: 'The Prince has definitely got what it takes.'

Early Ardent commissions included an appreciation of real tennis, the Prince's hobby, and Annie's Bar, a political soap opera made for Channel 4 but axed after one series. Edward on Edward, a documentary about Prince Edward's great uncle Edward VII, was sold all over the world, as was the Crown and Country series. But both attracted criticism that the Prince was trading on his royal connections.

Sophie Rhys-Jones, who married Edward last June, has also been accused of trading on her royal links to help her public relations company, R-JH, which has represented Rover as well as a string of society clients.

Last year, Edward was embroiled in controversy after agreeing to sell footage of his wedding to TV companies. A drama about the Queen Mother was cancelled after the subject reportedly protested.

The Prince has shown some entrepreneurial initiative in the past two years. He earned a reported £200,000 fee for a seven-day speaking programme in the United States. He gave an after-dinner address at a £129-a-head dinner at a London hotel to launch a book accompanying his Crown and Country series. And he was said to have received £30,000 for a lecture on the 1992 fire and restoration at Windsor Castle.

The Earl and Countess of Wessex, currently on a trip to Brunei, receive £96,000 a year from the Queen's Civil List payments to cover the cost of official engagements. Last week, the couple and their staff were in Malaysia, where Edward was criticised for putting a trade fair exhibit on his head.

fields.headline: No hassle for Blues
fields.trailText: London rivals poles apart after Chelsea stroll to victory.
fields.body:
They started as two mid-table wannabes striving for the momentum to lift an erratic, sometimes turblent season. They ended poles apart, Chelsea lengthening their stride and leaping to sixth in the Premiership, while Tottenham trooped off to digest another dose of disappointment and catcalls of discontent. The difference was encapsulated by Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink.

Chelsea's £15 million striker, pushed towards international acclaim by George Graham when the pair joined forces at Leeds United, reminded his former manager exactly what is missing from Tottenham. He has steely attitude, relishes responsibility, and possesses the class to turn chances into goals. A confident penalty and a classic piledriver took his tally to 10 in 11 Premiership games. 'Goals are Jimmy's blood,' proclaimed Claudio Ranieri.

fields.headline: Mighty Merson is still magic
fields.trailText: Paul Merson puts on a show as Villa dig in for victory.
fields.body:
Regrets? Paul Merson has had a few during his life, which has had so many ups and downs it has resembled a snakes-and-ladders board at times, and the Aston Villa player must now be ruing the fact that he called time on his England career last year.

The former Arsenal forward is 32 going on 21, which is why Villa manager John Gregory gave him a one-year extension to his contract earlier this week.

Merson responded with a marvellous display of guile and graft against Charlton, chasing and caressing the ball in equal measure and scoring what proved to be the winner with a rare headed goal in the 41st minute.

And with England crying out for inspiration from the middle, Merson is the sort of player the new coaching set-up can ill-afford to ignore. Certainly Gregory thinks he could be persuaded to change his mind should Peter Taylor and Steve McClaren think he is worth another chance.

'If he got the call to play for England again I'm sure he'd jump at the opportunity,' said Gregory. 'Everything about him is good - his contribution to the team, his ability to score goals, his persona about the place. He inspires people and they look to him to score goals out of nothing.'

Indeed, his goal yesterday showed that although he has been playing a deeper role in recent years, his striker's instincts are still razor sharp. When Alan Wright whipped in a cross from the left, the ball was heading for the arms of Dean Kiely until Merson appeared from nowhere to glance a header past the bemused goalkeeper.

It was just reward for his relentless running and probing, which had given Villa the edge in a poor first-half. They had taken the lead in the 34th minute when Ian Taylor was given time and space to nod Steve Stone's deep cross into the far corner, and were comfortably ahead by half-time.

'We didn't apply ourselves or close down Villa in the first-half and I couldn't wait for the break so we could do something about it,' said Charlton's manager Alan Curbishley. 'For the second away game running we've given the opposition a two-goal start and blown a chance to get something out of it.'

Charlton pushed Villa all the way, though, with Dion Dublin diverting Jonatan Johansson's cross into his own goal in the closing minutes to set up a tense finale. But Villa dug in for a victory that allowed them to replace Charlton in seventh place and leave Gregory smiling.

fields.headline: Foxes finally find the net
fields.trailText: Leicester's goal drout is but a memory as Rams stay bottom.
fields.body:
After six goalless hours and defeats to Manchester United and Liverpool, Leicester finally rediscovered their scoring touch to right what had been a season in danger of serious decline. 'It was important to win after the two defeats,' said Peter Taylor, their manager. 'Now the league table looks nice again.'

Amid a swirling wind and constant rain, it was a day for close control and fine passing. But all three goals were controlled long-range strikes that gave the two keepers no chance.

Derby, without a win and marooned in last place, took a surprise lead against what is still a sturdy defence. Rory Delap was the scorer, receiving the ball 25 yards from goal and turning to arrow a shot past Tim Flowers.

But Flowers gained revenge by claiming an assist in the equaliser, his long clearance finding Muzzy Izzet who took the ball in his stride before hammering a 25-yard shot past Mart Poom.

Derby had impressed in the first half but faltered in the second. The home side gradually increased in dominance, but when the inevitable goal arrived it was from an unlikely source. Arnar Gunnlaugson, loaned out to Stoke City last season, came off the bench to score with his first touch. And what a touch it was, stroking the ball over Poom from, you guessed it, about 25 yards.

'I can understand Leicester supporters being desperate for us to win this game,' said Taylor. 'I presume that if we had not got the three points they might have thought that some of my thoughts were elsewhere, but that is a load of rubbish.'

Taylor has to prepare Leicester for games against Crystal Palace and Manchester City in the next week but will have to turn his thoughts to England at some point. He will squeeze in a meeting with his international assistant Steve McClaren to discuss the squad for next month's Italy game.

How his opposite number Jim Smith must dream of such distractions. His only worry now is when the axe will fall on his increasingly unpopular reign. For now he is waiting for Colin Todd's expected arrival from Swindon, 'a crazy situation now in the hands of the lawyers'.

'We deserved something from the game but they scored with two tremendous strikes,' Smith said. 'It shows that when things aren't going for you that sort of thing can happen. But my lads gave everything in terms of endeavour.'

fields.headline: Dutch courage absent at Ibrox
fields.trailText: Rangers' current status as the fourth-best team in Scotland may be only temporary; on the evidence of this latest drubbing, comprehensively outplayed by an impressive Kilmarnock (third best), they could soon be dropping further. Ill-served by too many players lacking the requisite skills and character, their fans showed much more class when they applauded the winners from the field. It was recognition that was thoroughly meted.
fields.body:
Rangers' current status as the fourth-best team in Scotland may be only temporary; on the evidence of this latest drubbing, comprehensively outplayed by an impressive Kilmarnock (third best), they could soon be dropping further. Ill-served by too many players lacking the requisite skills and character, their fans showed much more class when they applauded the winners from the field. It was recognition that was thoroughly meted.

Whatever other elements have gone into the building of the run of 11 unbeaten matches that Kilmarnock boast, composure and self-belief would be two of the least perishable. Visitors to Ibrox are not exactly famous for demonstrating the kind of no-sweat defending that forced Rangers to complete an entire first half without so much as a solitary scoring attempt.

The Ayrshire side were just as sanguine at the other end, collecting goals in the kind of matter-of-fact manner normally witnessed in a training session.

As Kilmarnock moved fluently around the field - the defence orchestrated by Freddie Dindeleux, the midfield revolving around Ian Durrant, the attack effective because of the intelligent running of Andy McLaren - even the most prejudiced home fan would have to concede that they were simply the better team.

Rangers continued to suffer from the inadequate contributions of players from whom they would expect more, notably Ronald de Boer, Arthur Numan and Neil McCann. De Boer, returned to midfield, appeared to lack conviction and commitment, McCann was policed mercilessly by Gus MacPherson and Numan continued to look a bad imitation of the player he was for Holland at France 98.

Kilmarnock were, indeed, quicker than the home side in every area and intelligent in their ability to anticipate moves. Rangers were mainly frustrated by their visitors' constantly being in a position to steal possession. None of this, of course, appealed to the frustrated home fans, who finished up booing the captain, Lorenzo Amoruso, as he shaped to take a free-kick close to the penalty area.

Perhaps realising that the fans were on his case the big Italian steeped aside for de Boer, who then drove the ball into the defensive wall.

Kilmarnock had no such problems when they drove forward, their early opening goal typical of their incisiveness when presented with opportunities. Cristophe Cocard took a long pass from midfield and cut inside from the right, passing Amoruso, before laying off to McLaren on the left.

The winger's return was impeccable, the centre low and perfectly weighted to the right foot of Cocard, who had only to slip it over the line from six yards. It was a beautifully worked strike that was, extraordinarily, matched by their second.

This time it was Durrant who delivered the precise pass through the middle for Holt, who fended off the desperately challenging Numan as he dragged the ball on to his left foot before clipping it past Jesper Christiansen from 10 yards.

Dick Advocaat's response to this adversity was predictable and very Dutch; he simply threw more forwards at the problem, sending the penalty-box predator, Billy Dodds, on in place of Kanchelskis and replacing full-back Sergio Porrini with Kenny Miller.

No material difference was effected by these alterations, execpt that Kilmarnock went further ahead. Once again, there was no arguing with their goal. They had continued to be the more accomplished team, with crisp passing, foxy defending and powerful surges in attack.

That third goal typified their versatility, as it was begun by Dindeleux, the French defender taking possession at half-way and pushing deep into Rangers territory. Once there, he released the pass to his compatriot, Cocard, on the right.

Cocard found McLaren on the wide left with a brilliantly controlled delivery and, when the winger-cum-striker's centre zipped across the goal area, it came off the leg of Christiansen, struck Numan and ran over the line. Not only has Rangers' form, self-belief and harmony deserted them, they appear also to have been divorced by the luck that is invariably the partner of champions.

fields.headline: Arsenal's five-star show
fields.trailText: Wenger boys demolish ten-man City.
fields.body:
Still 100 per cent at home, unbeaten in 15 games since the opening day of the season, Arsenal's thoroughbreds are England's form horses, as well as Europe's. Heaven help opponents if they start taking more of the goal-scoring chances they create.

Five goals, believe it or not, were slim pickings for the sustained opulence of Arsenal's slick passing and swift movement - though, paradoxically, testimony to the goalkeeping of Manchester City's Nicky Weaver. They will hardly credit it - given the result from their Manchester rivals, which highlighted, like this one, how far ahead of the rest are the Premiership's top two - but it could have been a double-figure day.

Naturally the City manager, Joe Royle, pointed to the sending-off of Danny Tiatto two minutes before half-time as the game's turning point, Arsene Wenger also conceding it to be 'decisive'. The real turning point came 30 seconds later, however, when Ashley Cole struck home a low shot from 20 yards after the resultant free-kick was touched to him by Dennis Bergkamp.

'We were doing fine, 11 v 11,' said Royle. 'The referee's decision changed the game. After that, it was effectively over but I can't say too much because I'll get in trouble. Arsenal are a terrific side and they don't need any help.'

Royle's complaints were - in order - that Thierry Henry should have been sent off for a kick at Spencer Prior, and that Tiatto should not have been shown his first yellow card. Add to that a hand-ball claim for Arsenal's fourth goal and an offside for their fifth, and it left City's fans singing 'Five-nil to the referee'.

In truth, it was straw-clutching. Henry might have deserved a yellow for his flick of the foot at Prior, after being shoved first by the City defender, and the fourth was indeed a hand ball missed by the referee, Rob Styles. Otherwise, it was a question of when Arsenal would score and how many.

In midfield, Patrick Vieira was irresistible, all elegance and energy in controlling the game's rhythm, his contest with the willing artisan Alf Inge Haaland a microcosm of the difference between the teams.

At the outset, it was the familiar Highbury pattern. The visitors come with two banks of four in defence and midfield, sitting deep in an attempt to repel the red tide and hoping to make ripples on the break. And for much of the first half it was the familiar Arsenal pattern of carving openings but failing to finish. 'I was not convinced then we would win the game,' said Wenger.

The doubts were induced by Henry clipping Ray Parlour's pass into the side netting and Weaver kicking away another shot after the Frenchman had danced past Prior and Steve Howey. In addition, the goalkeeper flew to divert a shot by Robert Pires, who also headed Henry's cross wide.

Then came the Tiatto incident - he might have been better letting him run, given the way Henry was misfiring at this point - and Cole's opening goal, sweetly struck low into Weaver's left corner. As Wenger said: 'It does concern me that we miss chances, but we have so many lively and mobile players on the field that I believe we will always create more.'

A minute later the 39-year-old John Lukic, playing his first Premiership game for more than three years as deputy for the injured David Seaman, turned aside Shaun Goater's drive. It proved a token gesture. Normal service was resumed in the second half.

Freddie Ljungberg's neat backheel created space for Dennis Bergkamp to guide home a low shot and after that it was what Ron Atkinson would describe as a 'floodgates job'. Sylvain Wiltord, coming off the bench, tucked Henry's defence-splitting pass through Weaver's legs before returning the compliment with interest. First, his cross from the right bounced up from foot to hand before Henry lashed home, though for the fifth it needed only one touch to lift over Weaver and make it Henry - the eighth of the season.

It was something of a pyrrhic victory, with Vieira (groin), Pires (hamstring) and Luzhny (knee) all joining Arsenal's injury list, though City will feel no sympathy for a side who could leave Kanu on the bench. As well as the ref to groan about, their long-suffering supporters, who admirably sang continuously, also had to endure an early contender for miss of the millenium, Goater scooping over a gaping goal from seven yards.

Perhaps the expression a 'Goater of a miss' could enter the game's parlance. Arsenal are certainly vulnerable to them, even if they do make rich amends.

fields.headline: 'Terrific' says Burley
fields.trailText: Ipswich up to fifth with a feast of free-flowing football.
fields.body:
These are prosperous times for Ipswich, unbeaten in six games, up to fifth in the table and fully deserving to be there.

While the manager, George Burley, continues to insist that fourth from bottom would be an achievement at the end of the season, there is a freshness and confidence about his team which suggests much more.

This scoreline did scant justice to another free-flowing performance which promised a sackful after goals by Richard Naylor and Mark Venus in quick succession, midway through the first half.

Middlesbrough were fortunate to run them so close, although it was difficult not to feel some sympathy for a side ravaged by injuries. Key men - Alen Boksic, Paul Ince and record signing Ugo Ehiogu - were among those missing, and Brian Deane became the latest casualty when he was carried off on a stretcher with concussion.

In that position, the last thing they needed was to hand Ipswich the opening goal on a plate. But the goalkeeper's clearance was driven straight to Naylor, who promptly hit it straight back into an empty net from 30 yards.

Matt Holland hit a post, and Marcus Stewart and John McGreal saw efforts scrambled away from near the line. A chance wasted by Hamilton Ricard - replaced before half- time - was Middlesbrough's only response until Dean Gordon's 25-yard free kick took a deflection and wrong-footed Richard Wright.

fields.headline: Xavier's quality of Mersey
fields.standfirst: The Portuguese 'bad boy' is still haunted by Euro 2000 as he seeks a lucrative move abroad
fields.trailText: The Portuguese 'bad boy' is still haunted by Euro 2000 as he seeks a lucrative move abroad.
fields.body:
For a man whose eclectic tonsorial taste apparently owes its current inspiration to Prince, it should come as no surprise that Everton's Abel Xavier has undergone more reincarnations than even the diminutive rock star.

The player formerly known as a mediocre Premiership utility man emerged from Euro 2000 not only with a striking hairstyle, but as a full-back of world-class calibre, with faxes from Roma and Benfica, among others, confirming that fact.

Xavier also, of course, emerged with more than that. After he handled Sylvain Wiltord's extra-time shot in the semi-final with France, the resulting 'golden goal' penalty cost Portugal a place in the final and led Xavier towards a remonstration with referee Gunter Benko.

The nine-month Uefa suspension that followed, unsuccessfully appealed against twice by player and Everton, cost the 27-year-old from Mozambique the opportunity of a lucrative overseas transfer, Walter Smith some much-needed transfer profit on a player who cost only £1.6 million from PSV Eindhoven 13 months ago, and could still be the subject of litigation as Xavier seeks 'justice'.

Gérard Houllier, with whom Xavier will renew his acquaintance in today's Anfield derby, will probably not be rushing forward to act as a character witness in those proceedings. After the defender's second taste of a Merseyside derby, the goalless Goodison draw late last season, the Liverpool manager was highly critical of Xavier's man-marking of Emile Heskey.

Yet such brushes with authority and opponents belie the fact that Xavier is far more than a throwback to the days when Hispanic hatchet men ruled Europe by fear. After Euro 2000, the president of Mozambique, Joaquim Chissano, wrote to Xavier personally to sympathise and the player is currently involved in charity work with the African country's marginally more famous football product, Eusebio, to provide assistance to the millions effected by this year's floods.

'I had a lot of support from Mozambique after Euro 2000, their letters touched me a lot. The president wrote to me,' he said. 'In Mozambique, the people do not have anything to eat but they are following football, following the Portuguese team. They know where players play, they know Everton, they know me, what I've done here. That is why the ban was so frustrating, the people don't understand why I was given it.'

Ah yes, the ban. The chances of talking to Xavier for more than three minutes without the topic cropping up are, presumably, the same as having a conversation with Prince without using the word 'sex'.

Still protesting the handball was accidental, Xavier insists he never accosted the referee and claims an unfair Uefa hearing amid the sort of conspiracy theories that probably have Oliver Stone bidding for movie rights as we speak.

'I am still very clear in my mind what happened at that moment,' said Xavier about the post-penalty protests. 'It wasn't necessary to watch many times on video although when I went to the hearing in Geneva I saw the images and I still don't find I did anything violent.

'As a player you work hard towards different objectives and, at that time, I could have gone to a top European club. There were a few teams interested in me but the teams that are playing in the Champions League or Uefa Cup will not buy a player with a nine-month suspension.

'I showed Uefa faxes from the teams that were interested and begged them not to ban me, that they were going to affect my career, but I was not even allowed to defend myself. I don't want to make this a big case, the only thing I want now is justice, the damage is already done, so if it is possible to go further with it, I will.'

Content at Everton, for this season at least, Xavier can now look forward to a Mersey derby in which the pre-match hype has centred upon the reception Liverpool's Nick Barmby can expect from his former club and supporters. Interestingly, Xavier's friend Luis Figo endured a similar experience on his return to Barcelona with Real Madrid.

'I spoke with Figo this week and he was upset he was treated that way. But on the other hand, it has given him a clear view about his situation. He thinks he did a great job for Barcelona but he now knows where he stands with them and his current club.

'As for Nick Barmby, he was a top professional for Everton, did great work here and made his own decision. You cannot say why people choose to move but I have very good memories about Nick Barmby at this club.'

Xavier hopes the same will be said of him when he finally gets that lucrative move he so clearly desires. Perhaps a fresh start is what he needs to finally rid himself of the baggage he brought home from the Low Countries this summer.

Then again, perhaps he will miss it. The suspension has become as integral to the likeable Xavier's personality as the peroxide beard and hair and it comes as no surprise that the pair have a direct link.

'At the start, it was a joke before Euro 2000,' he explained. 'To make everybody laugh, to make me the talisman for the team. Then, when the side did well, I could not change it. Now there is the ban, I can't change. I must continue like this so everybody knows I was banned, and knows it was unfair ...'

fields.headline: Said & Done
fields.trailText: Taliban football: just do it
fields.body:
Taliban football: just do it

The uneasy relationship between the Taliban militia and re-emerging Afghan football worsened last week after armed religious police stormed a match and chased away the players to enforce a new law banning sport in the afternoon. Officials said the match was raided because it had gone 10 minutes beyond the 4pm deadline set by the Taliban supreme leader Mullah Mohammad Omar.

The incident was typical of the growing problems since football was re-authorised in 1998 after years of Islamic prohibition - during which the Kandahars football stadium was turned over exclusively to public executions and limb amputation (attracting 35,000 capacity crowds). In July this year, members of a visiting Pakistani junior team were arrested at gun point during a game because they arrived wearing shorts. 'Only five players were able to escape,' said captain Abdul Qayuum. 'The rest were rounded up and had their heads shaven as a punishment.' Supporters, meanwhile, are forbidden to clap, and instead are obliged - again at gun point - to cheer both sides equally with chants of 'Allahu Akbar'. As a result, the game is struggling to re-establish its popularity. 'Executions and punishments here at the stadium are excellent but do not mean the Islamic Emirate is not interested in sport,' says spokesman Mullah Abdul Shukur Motmain. 'I just hope the same number of people will come to see the matches.'

Leeds row: the ref was right

'Leeds sold down the Riva' blasted the Star last week after Rivaldo's Champions League injury time goal against Leeds: 'it was a ridiculous amount of extra time'. The Sun - 'Barc-ing mad' - agreed, David O'Leary 'couldn't understand it', the Yorkshire Post said it was 'the kind of overtime which used to pay for miners' holidays', and the Mirror wrote of the 'injustice of the phantom four minutes': 'What should have been a momentous occasion for David O'Leary's young team turned sour... Where the four extra minutes came from will remain a mystery.' Well - not quite. Observer IQ statisticans at Elland Road, using Uefa backed measures, saw straight away that the ref was right. In total, there were 3mins 43 seconds of stoppages - Rivaldo struck with 28 seconds to spare. Full details:

OBSERVER IQ: Second half stoppages, Leeds v Barcelona. 46th minute: Mills treatment 50 seconds; 49th minute: Abelardo yellow card 30 seconds; 65th minute: Barcelona substitutions - Dani for Luis Enrique, Gerard for Reiziger 32 seconds; 75th minute: Leeds substituion - Burns for Dacourt 39 seconds; 76th minute: Rivaldo disallowed goal 40 seconds; 89th minute: Bakke yellow card 32 seconds. TOTAL: 3 mins 43 seconds. RIVALDO GOAL: 93 minutes, 15 seconds.

Maradona: the absentee gaffer

A warning from Cuban doctors that Maradona's heart problem could recur after he accepted a return to football management should relax: despite 'looking forward immensely to the job' in Argentina, Maradona won't actually be leaving the country. According to Dr Alfredo Cahe, 'this is a significant risk - although, I suppose, he cannot stay in Cuba for ever.' Maradona evidently disagrees. After admitting privately to being underwhelmed by the modest size of his new club, Almagro, he's decided to manage them from his Cuban cottage - 4,200 miles away. 'At least someone has made me an offer and I suppose that's something,' he told friends. No-one, though, seems to have warned Almagro president Dardo de Marchi. 'Having Diego here will be like touching heaven,' he said last week. 'Maradona can show the world his true self, and maybe one day a new divine Maradona will emerge.'

Championship Manager: the winners

Winners of last week's CM00/01 competition (1.55m copies of the series have been sold worldwide): Liam O'Donnell, Merseyside; Patrick Simkins, Surrey; Greg Gordon, Glasgow; Anton Marks, London; Samantha Warrington, London; Gill James, Rugby; David Reynolds, Walsall; Patrick Doggett, Dublin; Ben Foote, Guernsey; Philipp Lohan, Montreal, Canada.

Tales from the Tabs

STUFF YOU COLLY

Bradford players have told Stan Collymore to forget about a long-term stay unless he proves he's not a nutter. The squad turned on the striker when the signing was announced - but Collymore says he's up for the challenge. 'All I want is to do right by this club.'

TITI BYE EVERYONE

Titi Camara has stormed out of Anfield after being left on the bench during Liverpool's Uefa Cup game on Thursday. Camara - who signed for £2.5m a year ago - wants a new Premiership club, but Man City have had an initial £3m enquiry knocked back.

 Arsène Wenger has repeated his fears for Arsenal once the new-look transfer system is in place: 'It will just make the footballing world even more unstable. You could meet your squad on a Thursday and by the Sunday after the game, half the players could've left.' Edu, meanwhile, is getting increasingly excited as his arrival in London nears: 'Arsenal is in my head and I can't get it out of my head.'

 Aston Villa could make a massive bid for Chelsea's Tore Andre Flo after ruling out a £13m deal for South African Benni McCarthy. Claudio Ranieiri will sell Flo for £8m.

 Bradford say they'll up Stan Collymore's reported £13,000-a-week plus £7,000-a-game salary if he scores regularly.

 Charlton have taken former Arsenal reserve midfielder Guilliaume Norbert on trial.

 Jesper Gronkjaer's agent has denied that the player has failed a Chelsea medical: 'It's rubbish. We've just had no decision yet.'

 Cedric Roussel says Gordon Strachan is right to drop him from Coventry's first team: 'I agree with Gordon.'

 Derby are still negotiating for Marseille defender Lilian Martin.

 Everton's Abel Xavier is a target for Benfica.

 Ipswich have denied agreeing to sell James Scowcroft to Leicester.

 Leeds ' goalkeeping love-in goes on: Nigel Martyn says Paul Robinson is 'an England keeper in waiting' - Robinson says Martyn is 'number one as far as I'm concerned.'

 Leicester won't be spending to end their goalscoring crisis: 'The goals we need are just around the corner,' says Peter Taylor.

 Liverpool are ready to extend Erik Meijer's loan at Preston.

 Norwich have taken Man City's Danny Granville on loan.

 Manchester United target Phillippe Mexes is being chased by Juventus - the young defender, 'the new Laurent Blanc', is rated at £5m by Auxerre.

 Middlesbrough are still watching Barnsley's Chris Morgan.

 Newcastle are keen on PSV defender Ernest Faber.

 Southampton are finally ready to sell James Beattie to Crystal Palace.

 Sunderland's Nicky Summerbee is set to quit - Bradford and Bolton are keen.  George Graham says Tottenham fans are misguided: 'I just wish the crowd would see our achievements'.

 Crewe boss Dario Gradi has denied talking to West Ham about teen striker Dean Ashton.

fields.headline: Palace show true grit
fields.trailText: There might be a lot to be said for describing your players publicly as 'lazy whingers'.
fields.body:
There might be a lot to be said for describing your players publicly as 'lazy whingers'.

If Crystal Palace's manager, Alan Smith, intended to motivate his men when he put the verbal boot in on them last week, it certainly did the trick yesterday. Palace, 1-0 ahead at Bolton, then found themselves 3-1 behind with 13 minutes to go. But instead of slipping to their seventh successive defeat, they made it 3-3; and the additional irony was that Clinton Morrison, one of the three Palace players singled out by Smith in his outburst, scored the equaliser in the last minute.

Though a number of managers and coaches agreed with Smith's disparaging remarks about the attitude of a number of modern-day players, Smith was told by his Palace chairman, Simon Jordan: 'Just stop bleating and get on with your job.' Inevitably, Brendan Batson of the Professional Footballers' Association was also less than enamoured by them.

However, the players themselves were happy to take the heat out of the situation. Midfielder Jamie Pollock said: 'This [the performance against Bolton] can be the turning point for the club. We've got a strong dressing- room spirit, and we responded to the manager's comments in the right way. This has all brought us closer together.'

Morrison, who has been transfer-listed with Hayden Mullins and Jamie Smith, added: 'I signed a four-year contract in August, and I am determined to stay here. We have taken the manager's words on board, and while we do not agree with everything he said, I know that I have not been doing it on the pitch, and sometimes I have not done all I should in training. But it was good to clear the air.'

As for Smith, he said: 'I was proud of the team out there today, and we gave a good day's work for a good day's pay. It is plain to see that my words in midweek have not been wasted. Some people thought I was a bit hard on the players but you don't get angry about people you do not care about.'

Two other notable examples of teams showing the character one expects from highly-paid professionals could be seen at Sheffield Wednesday and Wolves. Wednesday were also involved in a 3-3 draw at home to Fulham - some result, considering that they twice had to come from behind and had Alan Quinn sent off when Fulham were 2-1 ahead. They got their point through a last-minute goal by central defender Ashley Westood. Wolves achieved a 2-2 draw against the Division One leaders, Watford, after being 2-0 down at half- time.

Also earning full marks in this fighting-spirit department were the supporters who turned out on a dreadful afternoon to see their teams in action. Hence the fact that after Birmingham's 1-1 draw at Portsmouth, their man ager, Trevor Francis, made a point of going over to thank the fans behind one of the goals for their support, He said: 'The conditions were atrocious - some of the worst I have ever experienced. The fans had sat in the teeth of an amazing gale and had still kept up their chanting and support, but they played their part in helping us get a draw.'

With Huddersfield expected to appoint their new manager in succession to Steve Bruce this week, their caretaker, Lou Macari, was non-commital on his chances of landing the post after the 1-0 defeat by Blackburn: 'I would not like to have to rely on 90 minutes or a couple of games to get the job.'

Also linked with the position is Hearts' manager, Jim Jefferies. The post may have become more attractive to him after his team's 3-0 defeat by St Johnstone. Hearts are in financial trouble, and their performance yesterday led to 500 supporters staging a demonstration against the board.
