It is plain to see that my words in midweek have not been wasted. Some people thought I was a bit hard on the players but you don't get angry about people you do not care about.' Two other notable examples of teams showing the character one expects from highly-paid professionals could be seen at Sheffield Wednesday and Wolves. Wednesday were also involved in a 3-3 draw at home to Fulham - some result, considering that they twice had to come from behind and had Alan Quinn sent off when Fulham were 2-1 ahead. They got their point through a last-minute goal by central defender Ashley Westood. Wolves achieved a 2-2 draw against the Division One leaders, Watford, after being 2-0 down at half- time. Also earning full marks in this fighting-spirit department were the supporters who turned out on a dreadful afternoon to see their teams in action. Hence the fact that after Birmingham's 1-1 draw at Portsmouth, their man ager, Trevor Francis, made a point of going over to thank the fans behind one of the goals for their support, He said: 'The conditions were atrocious - some of the worst I have ever experienced. The fans had sat in the teeth of an amazing gale and had still kept up their chanting and support, but they played their part in helping us get a draw.' With Huddersfield expected to appoint their new manager in succession to Steve Bruce this week, their caretaker, Lou Macari, was non-commital on his chances of landing the post after the 1-0 defeat by Blackburn: 'I would not like to have to rely on 90 minutes or a couple of games to get the job.' Also linked with the position is Hearts' manager, Jim Jefferies. The post may have become more attractive to him after his team's 3-0 defeat by St Johnstone. Hearts are in financial trouble, and their performance yesterday led to 500 supporters staging a demonstration against the board.

webTitle: McManus edges Hibs closer to top

fields.headline: McManus edges Hibs closer to top
fields.trailText: Scottish League review.
fields.body:
Hibernian moved to within two points of Celtic yesterday, but few can have anticipated that bottom-of-the-table Dundee United would make them sweat so hard for it.

United, the only Premier League team without a win, seemed certain to get their third draw of the season. But Hibernian eventually got their noses in front through the 81st-minute substitution of David Zitelli by Tom McManus. The next minute, the youngster fastened onto a Russell Latapy pass to knock home his third goal of the season.

It was a match in which both teams had created good scoring chances, with United looking particularly dangerous in the early stages. How United must have bemoaned their failure to go ahead in the opening five minutes, when Steven Thompson had a shot saved by Nick Colgan when he was clean through with only the keeper to beat.

United's defeat was rendered even more disappointing by the 2-0 win by St Mirren, the team immediately above them, at home to Aberdeen. There was a strong element of luck about their first goal. It was against the run of play, and Scott Walker, the scorer, was handed the chance as a result of a hopelessly mishit Mark Yardley shot.

Yardley also set up Ricky Gillies for the Saints' second.

Dundee had yet another foreign player in their team for the visit to Dunfermline - goalkeeper Marco Roccati - but it was hardly the best of days for him or his colleagues as they fell to 1-0 defeat.

The decisive goal came after 60 minutes with an excellent David Moss header from Chris McGroaty's cross.

There was more misery for Hearts, who crashed 3-0 at home to St Johnstone. The match hinged on a controversial penalty at the start of the second half when Keigan Parker was adjudged to have been brought down by Kevin James. After Parker converted the spot-kick the floodgates opened.

Paddy Connolly then helped himself to a double as Hearts totally crumbled.

Not surprisingly, with Hearts having been humbled by Hibernian last weekend and conceded nine goals in the last two matches, the reaction of their fans was one of anger.

They produced a red-card protest against chief executive Chris Robinson, who was barracked throughout the game, and a sizeable number of supporters vented their anger after the game outside the main stand with calls for his board to resign.

'The boys are flying,' says Motherwell's Scott Leitch, referring to the fact that his team have won their past two matches. However, the sides they overcame - Dundee and St Johnstone - can hardly have been expected to provide the sort of challenge that Motherwell will experience today from Celtic.

One headache for Celtic in their bid to is that winger Bobby Petta has joined Chris Sutton in the treatment room after going over on his ankle in the 1-1 draw with Bordeaux.

Sutton missed the midweek game after suffering an ankle injury in the win over Dundee United, and the pair face late fitness tests.

fields.headline: Doncaster stay alive
fields.standfirst: As the FA Cup kicks off,  Ed Jones sees the Conference side fight back to draw
fields.trailText: As the FA Cup kicks off, Ed Jones sees the Conference side fight back to draw with Southport.
fields.body:
Question: is it better to be in the Football League, broke and attracting gates of fewer than 2,000, or in the Nationwide Conference and financially buoyant? Answer: ask Yorkshire rivals Doncaster and Halifax.

In 1998, doomed Doncaster fell out of the League after an appalling season that culminated in then chairman Ken Richardson attempting to burn down the main stand at Belle Vue, and subsequently going to prison. They were replaced by a rejuvenated Halifax, back in the big time after suffering the ignominy of relegation from the Football League themselves. But two years on, who is in the better position?

Halifax, who will play Gateshead in the first round of the FA Cup, are once again propping up the Third Division table, with new manager Paul Bracewell yet to record a victory. Doncaster, on the other hand, are being bankrolled to the tune of around £750,000 a year by their new owner and chairman, John Ryan, owner of Transform Medical UK, an elite cosmetic surgery business.

Yet all is not rosy in the Doncaster garden. The fans are not happy with the manager, Steve Wignall. The team, second favourites behind Rushden and Diamonds to lift the Conference title this season, are currently lie in eighth place, despite their full-time status and money having been spent on new players. The most expensive of those, £60,000 striker Carl Alford, has yet to score while the most familiar face in the team is captain Mark Atkins, Premiership Championship medal-winner with Blackburn Rovers.

Yesterday, it was time to turn attentions towards the battle to qualify for the first round proper of the FA Cup, the winners of this game being drawn away to either Havant or Gloucester.

And what a pulsating match it was. Southport, one of the few sides in the top half of the Conference not to be full time, are experiencing a rejuvenation under new manager Mark Wright, the former Oxford, Southampton, Derby, Liverpool and England defender. He has instilled in them a very fluid passing game which, in atrocious conditions, was only evident in spells here.

Doncaster took the lead straight after half time when Alford sent wing back Simon Marples racing down the right flank and he held of Stuart Whittaker to cut in on goal and slot coolly past Dickinson. The joy was short lived.

Southport could have equalised immediately when keeper Barry Richardson's clearance cannoned off the legs of striker Simon Parke's - the ball spun fully 30 yards in the air before landing on the line. But they were level when Richardson brought down former Doncaster striker Noureddine Maamria rather needlessly in the box. Ex-Liverpool midfielder Mike Marsh converted from the spot.

Southport's second was superb. Substitute Lee Elam seized upon a loose ball on the left, broke in and shrugged off two markers before chipping delicately passed the onrushing Richardson from just inside the area.

Doncaster threw everything at Southport and with just two minutes to go, when it looked as if the visitors had done enough to hold on midfielder Jamie Patterson produced an explosive climax. He weaved his way into the box, though two challenges and rifled a brilliant angled shot into the roof of the net to the delight of Belle Vue. The replay is on Tuesday at Haig Avenue.

Doncaster's assistant manager Alan Lewer said afterwards: 'We're disappointed not to win because we only really got going in the final quarter but I think in all fairness a draw was probably the right result and we are just pleased to still be in the competition. It's going to be a really tough match in the replay.'

Some surprisingly high attendances, made a mockery of the idea that the England's premier football competition is no longer the attraction it was. Even at this lowly stage in the proceedings, there was an all-ticket match as Easington Colliery took on Chester City. They lost 2-0 in the end, despite passionate support.

Elsewhere Barrow were watched by over a thousand as they put six past Whitley Bay - their reward a match against in-form Leyton Orient. Other plum ties include the winners of the postponed match between Aldershot and Dover Athletic who will play high-flying Brighton, Harrow Borough who meet Lawrie Sanchez's Wycombe and Welling United or Dorchester Town who take on Wigan.

fields.headline: A bitter pill for Advocaat
fields.standfirst: The Rangers manager is finding increased criticism hard to stomach as the pressure mounts
fields.trailText: The Rangers manager is finding increased criticism hard to stomach as the pressure mounts, writes Glenn Gibbons.
fields.body:
Until a month or so ago, the thought of Dick Advocaat coming under siege at Ibrox would have seemed to most Rangers supporters as preposterous as the notion of Nelson Mandela being reviled by South Africans.

But the events of the past few weeks - during which the Scottish champions' once-iridescent prospects of retaining their title and, perhaps more significantly, of progressing in the Champions League, were reduced to a mere glimmer - have brought a chilling change in the atmosphere. In football, the switch from acclaim to vituperation can be as instantaneous as turning off a light.

On Friday morning - less than 36 hours after last Wednesday night's 2-0 defeat by Sturm Graz in Austria, which leaves Rangers requiring victory over Monaco in their last match to be certain of making the top two in Group D of the premier European tournament - the Daily Records 'Hotline' column showed virtual unanimity among its callers that Advocaat should be sacked (yesterday's home defeat by Kilmarnock can hardly have helped).

While these vehicles for fans' frustrations should not be regarded as indicative of the mood of the majority, this particular edition did hint at a widespread intolerance of the manager and his methods.

It is as though the club's followers have, through these vexing few weeks, tired of Advocaat's tendency to advance a lengthy injury list or the unacceptable attitude of his players as reasons for the decline that has left them an alarming distance behind Celtic in the championship and menaced by elimination from Europe. They are, it would seem, resorting to a simple truth: that Advocaat signed them, coaches them and selects them, therefore their performances are directly attributable to his capabilities.

But perhaps most distressing of all for a support accustomed to unopposed supremacy at home, which started the campaign with high expectations of success abroad, is the growing impression of a damaging, potentially devastating, disharmony in the squad. As far back as 27 August, when they lost 6-2 to Celtic, there were unmistakable signs of discord, especially in defence.

That suspicion has recently hardened towards a conviction that there are serious rifts among the players, that a previously unheard of clannishness has developed in the dressing-room, which is following the team on to the field and consequently affecting their performances.

During the trip to Austria, the subject was raised with Advocaat and the manager appeared on the brink of startling candour before reining himself in, as if suddenly sniffing the possibility of revealing an unpalatable truth.

'I know things for myself,' he began. 'I know certain things which... well, perhaps I have to keep to myself.' As if realising that some repair work had to be carried out, he added: 'Disharmony or cliques? Mmm, no, I don't think so. You have to remember, football players are like everybody else. They will like certain colleagues better than others. It's like that in life, with other people, with journalists. There will be some colleagues you like better than others.'

The attempt at filling the cracks was fair, but it was impossible to escape the inference that factions have developed at Ibrox and that the previous togetherness has, by and large, disintegrated.

Having won five of the six major domestic trophies available in the two full seasons since he succeeded Walter Smith, Advocaat has become unaccustomed to mediocre performances and the seething criticism that accompanies them. This has been a testing time, but he insists there are reasons beyond his fault for the slump.

'The big problem this season has been the start,' he said. 'We still had an incomplete squad when we began. We started with only the hope, rather than the certainty, that Michael Mols would be fit. Other players had been at Euro 2000 and some were tired, others not fit.

'We had to wait and wonder if Mols could still do it and when it seemed that he was still troubled by his knee injury, we had to try to get another top-class striker and it hasn't been possible. Despite that, we kept winning until we played Celtic. Then we knew we had to make allowances for our problems, such as training hard or training soft, being careful to get things right.'

Advocaat had included in his severe criticism of the players after last Sunday's 2-1 defeat by St Johnstone the observation that too many of them were preoccupied with golf and personal websites and not concentrating enough on football. He was asked if the business of management had become more difficult in the modern era. 'I don't like to compare generations because it's stupid,' he said.

'We live in the year 2000, many things have changed and we have to cope with that. There is much more money, there are websites, there are more journalists, a bigger media. But we are paid enough money to handle it. And I know I can change things because we have the quality here to do it.'

Later in the week, Advocaat made the eyebrow-raising admission that, of the seven players he bought in the summer - Fernando Ricksen, Bert Konterman, Paul Ritchie, Allan Johnston, Peter Lovenkrands, Kenny Miller and Paul Reid - only the first two named were regarded as first-team recruits, the others being a mixture of 'cover' and 'for the future'.

This hardly squares with the frequent utterances from Advocaat and his chairman, David Murray, that they were strengthening the squad with a view to 'taking us to the next level in Europe' following last year's elimination from the Champions League at the end of the first-group phase.

It is clear that, if Advocaat is to recover the goodwill of his club's demanding followers, substantial reparation will have to be made in short order.

fields.headline: Hussain caught in a dilemma
fields.standfirst: The captain's role in one-day cricket must be more flexible if England hope to get the better of opponents and conditions
fields.trailText: The captain's role in one-day cricket must be more flexible if England hope to get the better of opponents and conditions, says Vic Marks.
fields.body:
England squandered the chance to gain an unassailable 2-0 lead in the one-day series in Lahore partly because of their own cluttered thinking, which has rarely been a feature of this regime. So they head off to Rawalpindi for the final one-day game tomorrow with the initiative lost, the series in the balance and an intriguing match in prospect. After the heavy dew under the lights of Karachi, the bugs and insects of Lahore, what awaits the players when the sun has set in Rawalpindi?

After the victory in Karachi on Tuesday, coach Duncan Fletcher spoke about the virtue of a settled batting order in one-day cricket. I wish he hadn't. I concede that there is much to be gained from a settled side but within that framework there should be plenty of flexibility. This was lamentably lacking on Friday in Lahore.

When England lost their first wicket, the score was 66 for one in the thirteenth over. Alec Stewart's dismissal to Mushtaq Ahmed's first ball was a tragi-comic affair, but Marcus Trescothick was going well and England were handily placed.

Now put yourself in the Pakistanis' boots. Who would you like to see coming to the crease to counter the spinners? Graeme Hick, Andrew Flintoff or Nasser Hussain? The answer, I suggest, is Hussain, who was, of course, the batsman to emerge from the dressing room.

England have two players with the potential to be destructive against spinners - Hick and Flintoff. When setting a target on batsman-friendly pitches, the most destructive batsmen should be offered the best conditions to grab the initiative.

This means allowing them to bat with freedom, before the spinners have settled and before the fall of too many wickets induces circumspection. In other words, Hick or Flintoff should have been sent out.

Instead Hussain, even though he battled away with typical tenacity, floundered and the pressure grew on his partners. As it happened, Hick performed with an air of resignation throughout the match. With England shackled, he was run out in a fashion that would have prep school coaches tearing their hair out and his off-breaks were anaemic.

Meanwhile Flintoff, the man the Pakistanis currently fear the most, was stranded with a hapless tail. What a waste. All the more so since Hussain had been carrying an ankle injury and there was every reason for him to drop down the order in Lahore.

I sense a tension about Hussain's role in the one-day team, in particular where he should bat.

Hussain, being a bright bloke, must be aware of his limitations and he seems hellbent on justifying his position by batting himself at three. Some have argued that he has to bat in the first three to warrant a place in the one-day side, a situation complicated by the fruitful alliance of Stewart and Trescothick as opening batsmen. I don't see why that should be the case.

In the sort of circumstances that prevailed on Friday he could put himself at six, where his adhesive qualities would be valuable as a safety valve. He would be charged with recovering the situation if the destructive men had failed. There is no disgrace in this role. Combined with his superb fielding and his leadership skills, these are enough to justify his place in the team.

After tomorrow, this will not be a significant issue though it will pop up again every time England embark on a one-day series.

What England will encounter time and time again in Pakistan are dry, holding pitches and the mischievous spinners, Mushtaq Ahmed and Saqlain Mushtaq. The home side's spinners may have been neutered by the dew of Karachi and Moin Khan's decision to bat first but they were formidable in Lahore. In response England's only trump card was Ashley Giles, who hardly represents an ace in the pack. Nonetheless he did not bowl too badly in Lahore and he can look forward to a lot of work in the Test series.

By Tuesday, that Test series will have the undivided attention of the England tourists, which brings me back to Flintoff. I think there is a strong argument for keeping him in Pakistan even though he is unable to bowl. This would be a very unEnglish thing to do, though Pakistan on tour have often ferried players to and fro apparently on a whim.

The only recent precedent for England adding to their touring squad even though there has been no injured player to replace occurred in India on the 1992-93 tour. And it was a disaster. On that spectacularly unsuccessful tour a young Ian Salisbury accompanied the party from the start as a net bowler, to gain experience and to proffer some wrist spin.

The idea was that he should stay for a fortnight before joining the 'A' tour. But he impressed within the comforting confines of the nets, was retained in the party and, remarkably, was picked ahead of John Emburey and Phil Tufnell for the first Test in Calcutta. Salisbury bowled poorly; the confidence of Tufnell, in particular, was shredded by Salisbury's continued presence in India and England disintegrated.

But that experience should not deter England from keeping Flintoff in Pakistan. I can, I'm afraid, envisage a situation where England have to win a Test to share the series. In which case the option of Flintoff, who on his day just could intimidate the Pakistani spinners and who could score quickly enough to change the balance of a match, is worth having. Alternatively a bold England might want to launch a pre-emptive strike in the first Test. The continuing presence of Flintoff, whose technique is currently suited to non-seaming pitches, would at least give England another option: more flexibility, a quality not be scorned in Pakistan.

Alec Stewart's dismissal to Mushtaq Ahmed's first ball was a tragi-comic affair, but Marcus Trescothick was going well and England were handily placed. Now put yourself in the Pakistanis' boots. Who would you like to see coming to the crease to counter the spinners? Graeme Hick, Andrew Flintoff or Nasser Hussain? The answer, I suggest, is Hussain, who was, of course, the batsman to emerge from the dressing room. England have two players with the potential to be destructive against spinners - Hick and Flintoff. When setting a target on batsman-friendly pitches, the most destructive batsmen should be offered the best conditions to grab the initiative. This means allowing them to bat with freedom, before the spinners have settled and before the fall of too many wickets induces circumspection. In other words, Hick or Flintoff should have been sent out. Instead Hussain, even though he battled away with typical tenacity, floundered and the pressure grew on his partners. As it happened, Hick performed with an air of resignation throughout the match. With England shackled, he was run out in a fashion that would have prep school coaches tearing their hair out and his off-breaks were anaemic. Meanwhile Flintoff, the man the Pakistanis currently fear the most, was stranded with a hapless tail. What a waste. All the more so since Hussain had been carrying an ankle injury and there was every reason for him to drop down the order in Lahore. I sense a tension about Hussain's role in the one-day team, in particular where he should bat. Hussain, being a bright bloke, must be aware of his limitations and he seems hellbent on justifying his position by batting himself at three. Some have argued that he has to bat in the first three to warrant a place in the one-day side, a situation complicated by the fruitful alliance of Stewart and Trescothick as opening batsmen. I don't see why that should be the case. In the sort of circumstances that prevailed on Friday he could put himself at six, where his adhesive qualities would be valuable as a safety valve. He would be charged with recovering the situation if the destructive men had failed. There is no disgrace in this role. Combined with his superb fielding and his leadership skills, these are enough to justify his place in the team. After tomorrow, this will not be a significant issue though it will pop up again every time England embark on a one-day series. What England will encounter time and time again in Pakistan are dry, holding pitches and the mischievous spinners, Mushtaq Ahmed and Saqlain Mushtaq. The home side's spinners may have been neutered by the dew of Karachi and Moin Khan's decision to bat first but they were formidable in Lahore. In response England's only trump card was Ashley Giles, who hardly represents an ace in the pack. Nonetheless he did not bowl too badly in Lahore and he can look forward to a lot of work in the Test series. By Tuesday, that Test series will have the undivided attention of the England tourists, which brings me back to Flintoff. I think there is a strong argument for keeping him in Pakistan even though he is unable to bowl. This would be a very unEnglish thing to do, though Pakistan on tour have often ferried players to and fro apparently on a whim. The only recent precedent for England adding to their touring squad even though there has been no injured player to replace occurred in India on the 1992-93 tour. And it was a disaster. On that spectacularly unsuccessful tour a young Ian Salisbury accompanied the party from the start as a net bowler, to gain experience and to proffer some wrist spin. The idea was that he should stay for a fortnight before joining the 'A' tour. But he impressed within the comforting confines of the nets, was retained in the party and, remarkably, was picked ahead of John Emburey and Phil Tufnell for the first Test in Calcutta. Salisbury bowled poorly; the confidence of Tufnell, in particular, was shredded by Salisbury's continued presence in India and England disintegrated. But that experience should not deter England from keeping Flintoff in Pakistan. I can, I'm afraid, envisage a situation where England have to win a Test to share the series. In which case the option of Flintoff, who on his day just could intimidate the Pakistani spinners and who could score quickly enough to change the balance of a match, is worth having. Alternatively a bold England might want to launch a pre-emptive strike in the first Test. The continuing presence of Flintoff, whose technique is currently suited to non-seaming pitches, would at least give England another option: more flexibility, a quality not be scorned in Pakistan.

webTitle: Travel news: Explorers take internet path

fields.headline: Explorers take internet path
fields.trailText: An internet site is giving people the chance to ask questions and share travel tips online with famous travellers, explorers and celebrities.
fields.body:
An internet site is giving people the chance to ask questions and share travel tips online with famous travellers, explorers and celebrities such as Sir Ranulph Fiennes, Robin Hanbury-Tenison and Valerie Singleton. Internet users registering at www.travelleronline.com will be emailed the dates and times of all upcoming chat forums with information on how to participate.

Explorer Colonel John Blashford-Snell and BBC news reporter Kate Adie kicked off the series of monthly chats and the next scheduled event is with mountaineer Sir Chris Bonington on 29 November at 6.30pm.

Jonathan Lorie, editor of the chat forums, said: 'It's a wonderful way for ordinary people to make direct contact with inspirational people who they only read about in the newspaper or see on television. It's much more informal than a radio or TV interview, so the celebrities tend to be quite relaxed, leading to some quite frank discussions.'

The site aims to be a complete travel resource with health and travel guides, airline schedules and hotel listings, a secure holdall for storing personal information and passport details online, a free email service for travellers and a call forwarding and mobile phone hire service.

fields.headline: Let's go!
fields.standfirst: Ten things to do today
fields.trailText: Ski and Snowboard Show | Fireworks and Laser Spectacular | Celtic Hallowe'en
fields.body:
Check out the latest winter sports equipment and see displays of freestyle skiing and snowboarding on the Virtual Reality Mountain at the Daily Mail Ski and Snowboard Show at London's Olympia. Open 10am-6pm. Admission on the door is £10 adults, £5 children (0990 900090).

Catch the Fireworks and Laser Spectacular at Alton Towers (01538 702200). Admission to the Staffordshire theme park includes the evening fireworks, laser and music show at 7pm. Cost is £21 adults and £17 children for a full-day ticket. £12.50 adults and £10.50 children for admission after 3pm.

Celebrate Celtic Hallowe'en at the Archaeolink Prehistory Park in Aberdeenshire (01464 851500). There will be maskmaking, fire-eating and storytelling before the giant wickerman is burnt to welcome the beginning of the Celtic year. Open 10am to 5pm. Cost £5 adults, £3 children.

Buy an original artwork at the Affordable Art Fair in Battersea Park (0115 912 9166). There are 130 stalls and prices range from £30 to £2000. Open 11am-5pm. Cost £7.50 adults, children free.

Stock up on healing crystals and organic bathroom products at the Complementary Medicine Festival in Ilkley's Winter Gardens, West Yorkshire. Open 10am-6pm. Cost £2 adults, children free (01943 609 454).

Hear tales of medieval witchcraft and a mysterious white lady during Hallowe'en Tours of Kenilworth Castle (01926 852 078) near Coventry. Tours will take place at 11am and 2.30pm and there will be a treasure hunt for children. Open 10am to 5pm. Cost £3.50 adults, £1.80 children.

Last chance to catch the Two Painters exhibition of work by Cornish artist Alfred Wallis - famed for his 'naive' style of painting marine and harbour scenes- and James Dixon, also known for his portraits of the sea at the Tate Gallery St Ives, Cornwall (01736 796226). Open 10.30am-5.30pm. Admission £3.95 adults, children free.

The Centrestage Black Arts Festival at the Institute of Contemporary Arts (020 7930 3647) in London has black artists and performers from both sides of the Atlantic. Today there will be a hip-hop workshop at 5.30pm and a performance of music and spoken word from 7.30pm-10pm. Cost £12.

Take a guided Dusk Tour through the gardens and woodland of the fifteenth-century Speke Hall in Liverpool. Cost £6 adults, £3 children (0345 585702).

Enjoy readings and play extracts from Shakespeare and Charles Dickens as the Southwark Festival gets under way. Shakespeare Day is from 11am to 3.30pm and Dickens evening starts at 7pm. Ring festival hotline to check availability and prices (020 7403 7400).

webTitle: A top hotel manager reveals all

fields.headline: A top hotel manager reveals all
fields.standfirst: Sekkal, concierge at the Radisson SAS Royal Hotel, Copenhagen.
fields.trailText: Sekkal, concierge at the Radisson SAS Royal Hotel, Copenhagen
fields.body:
Any famous guests?

A few years ago Nelson Mandela stayed and I had the privilege of meeting him. I even asked him for an autograph for my son - we are not supposed to ask but it was Nelson Mandela after all. The Dalai Lama was a guest some time ago, as were The Beatles, but I never saw security like the time Yasser Arafat stayed. The whole hotel was shut down.

What sort of guests usually stay?

The summer tourist season is from June to September so it is mainly business guests now. And architects from all over the world.

Architects?

Yes, the hotel was designed by Arne Jakobsen, a Dane and one of the greatest architects of the twentieth century, so architects and students come to see it. Copenhagen is a great place to visit if you are interested in good design: there is also a shop originally opened in 1904 by the famous Copenhagen silversmith Georg Jensen and the Bang & Olufsen centre.

So the shopping must be pretty good?

The main shopping streets are in the Old Town and because the buildings date from the seventeenth and eighteenth century they are very pretty. However, there is a very high tax of 25 per cent so it can be expensive, although Americans and the Japanese can get a tax refund at the airport on whatever they have bought.

What about a day out?

There are lots of great museums and galleries, such as the National Museum and a new museum called Glyptotek, which was a gift from the brewery Carlsberg to Copenhagen. It houses ancient Egyptian, Roman and Greek collections as well as art. Pivoli Park nearby, which dates from 1855, will be open from 17 November to 23 December for a Christmas market. I expect there'll be quite a few Santa Clauses.

And a night out?

Kommandment is the only Michelin two-star restaurant in Copenhagen but there are lots of gourmet restaurants: King Hans is very hot right now. Our own restaurant, Summit, is on the twentieth floor and has a beautiful panoramic view of the city. Konrads and Cafe Victor are the best places for young people.

Hotel reservations: 0800 374 411

Rooms from £101

www.radissonsas.com

fields.headline: White stuff for boarders
fields.trailText: World Snowboarding Guide 2001 | Time Out Guide: New Orleans
fields.body:
World Snowboarding Guide 2001 by Tony Brown (Ice Publishing, £11.95)

This is a guide for those after snowboarding advice with attitude. The writing is cocky and colloquial. Information is frank and straightforward, but although it does assess conditions for beginners, the book is aimed at a young set of serious thrill-seekers. An excellent quick reference panel of mountain, snow and travel data accompanies the write-up of each resort. Advice on safety, job-finding and top tips from riders complete what is an impressive guide, but prepare for a good dose of snowboarding 'cool'.

Time Out Guide: New Orleans (Penguin, £10.99)

The party spirit of 'The Big Easy' has found its way into this high-spirited and snappy second-edition guide. Written with a clear love for the city, it engrosses you with tales of New Orleans's colourful history, arts scene and Mardi Gras festival. Steering you away from tourist traps, 'top tens' help you sort through the sights, music venues and shops. Sections cover every angle of city life, with suggestions for children, as well as advice for disabled visitors. And if the fun gets too much, simply take a trip out of town.

fields.headline: Up close and very personal
fields.standfirst: Stephanie Merritt  shares her terrace with a hungry elephant and gets into a staring match with a lioness on a safari holiday that delivers luxury and adventure
fields.trailText: Stephanie Merritt shares her terrace with a hungry elephant and gets into a staring match with a lioness on a safari holiday that delivers luxury and adventure.
fields.body:
'Please don't be worried - she can't see you,' whispered Johnson, our safari guide, who was displaying an unseemly amusement at my naked terror. Clearly his expertise was the greater, but I wasn't convinced - 'she' being a lioness the size of a Shetland pony who was standing two feet from my right leg and looking right at me with luminescent yellow eyes and the same contemptuous glare Sheryl Potts used to give me in the playground as she decided whether or not to lamp me.

'She can only see the truck,' Johnson elaborated. 'So just make sure you don't move suddenly,' he added - unnecessarily, I thought, since I was riveted to my seat. The rest of our party were cheerfully snapping away like paparazzi, but then they didn't have a lion (with teeth) sniffing their foot through the open side of the truck.

Just then, as if on cue, the rest of the pride appeared out of the bush; about 12 altogether, females and cubs, and surrounded us, stalking quietly around the truck with a kind of haughty curiosity. There's an instinctive fear, of course, but also incredulity - you have to remind yourself that this is not a zoo, nor is it television, and no matter how much you may have paid for it, these animals are not here for your entertainment. This is Botswana, and you're in the middle of a grassy plain so vast and so flat you fancy you can see the curvature of the earth at the endless horizon, under a towering, empty sky, and these lions could kill you if they felt like it. Fortunately, they did n't, and they rarely do - unless, like the Japanese man Johnson told us about, you're actually stupid enough to get out of the truck so you can be in a photo with the lion. But their proximity makes you realise just how far from civilisation you really are out here. It's as well, then, that the Botswana guides are so highly trained; guns are banned in the national parks, which means that the animals are less wary of humans, having never heard the sound of gunshot. It also means that your only protection is the knowledge and responses of your guide, who can read the landscape and the mood of the animals from hundreds of yards away.

We had arrived in Botswana after a two-hour flight from Johannesburg to Maun, the operations centre of the Okavango Delta, where most of the country's safari industry is based. Here we were met by Gametrackers' operations manager, Malcolm, who may have been the bastard child of Indiana Jones and Crocodile Dundee - a sort of Platonic ideal of a safari guide so replete with testosterone he made the bull elephants look limp-wristed. We then transferred by light aircraft to Savute Elephant Camp, the first of the three Gametrackers lodges, but not before I'd had a screaming fit on the landing strip when the pilot began complaining of temporary blackouts brought on by his drink problem. (Yes, I know anyone else would have realised it was a joke, but I'd only had an hour's sleep. The previous night we'd stayed in the five-star Westcliff Hotel in Johannesburg, the wine was unbelievable and, more importantly, free and half the England rugby team was in the swimming pool. Well, you wouldn't have gone to bed either.)

Savute is situated in the Chobe National Park, on the fringe of the Kalahari desert and - as the name suggests - is home to large herds of bull elephants during the dry season. The camp is almost as spectacular as the fauna, comprising a central dining room, lounge and bar resembling some colonial residence from the last days of the Raj, with 12 cabins charmingly (and deceptively) called 'tents'. They are, in fact, plush, thatched, air-conditioned canvas chalets with electric sockets and hot showers, and are so comfortable you could easily believe yourself in a five-star hotel room were it not for the elephants truffling about outside.

I was reminded of that old joke - 'How do you know when an elephant's been in your fridge?' 'There are footprints in the butter' - on the first afternoon I woke from a nap to find a very large elephant indeed snorting about on my verandah. Okay, it wasn't actually on the verandah, but its trunk was, and we watched each other from a distance of about three feet with a guarded mutual curiosity for a few minutes until it had snuffled up all the pods from the surrounding trees and decided to lumber off. The animals are free to wander in and out of the camp, which is why you are not allowed to go outside your tent without a guide after dark, but the elephants harrumph around during the day and you just have to wait politely for them to move on before attempting to get past. Steve and June, the camp managers, showed us evidence of nocturnal visits from the local hyena - chewed cushions, a half-eaten visitors' book - and told us of the times when lions and cheetahs had been found wandering the camp at night. Fortunately we had to contend with nothing more menacing than the monkeys who, well-versed in the camp's feeding timetable, would bounce around in the rafters of the dining room, poised to swoop down and nick the food from your plate if you were foolish enough to take your eyes off it.

It was winter in southern Africa, so our morning and evening game drives were fairly cold, although during the day it was hot enough to swim and sunbathe. Late rains this year meant that we were lucky enough to see herds of zebra, who would usually have migrated from the area earlier, and clusters of giraffes, elegant and melancholic, strolling by the scrubby trees that dotted the grassland. There were jackals, baboons, multi-coloured hornbills, okapi, elephants - so plentiful that our guide would simply wave a hand nonchalantly whenever we saw one and say, 'A. B. E.' (Another Big Elephant) - and, my favourites, a family of warthogs, trotting cheerfully in single file across our path like cartoon characters. In the evenings, the air was thick with the smell of wild sage and warm earth, and the evening drive would include a stop by a waterhole, where our guide would unpack a hamper of cold beers and gin and tonics, and we watched the breathtaking neon sunset, listened to the cries of the birds and vowed never to go back to London.

Unfortunately it's not quite that simple. Botswana is not a place for itinerant gap-year students and jobbing back-packers. The government has decided, very wisely, to place stringent limits on the development of the tourist industry, restricting the number of lodges, and encouraging luxury safari operators such as Gametrackers/Orient Express as part of a 'high cost, low numbers' policy. This has the advantage of preserving the landscape, leaving the parks and reservations as free from human activity and close to the animals' natural habitat as possible.

The following day, our gung-ho Kiwi pilot returned in the little Cessna to take us from Savute to Eagle Island Camp in the heart of the Okavango Swamp. From the plane you can watch the landscape changing beneath you, from dry grassland to pools and rivulets fringed with trees and plants; the rains had been heavy this year, and our pilot pointed out rivers which were flowing for the first time in 30 years, though my fellow passengers seemed distracted from the view when I took over the controls for a few minutes.

At Eagle Island, the layout of the camp was similar, but the game-viewing was all done by boat, and the biggest danger here was not lions but hippos. Despite their plump, smiley expressions, hippos, our guide informed us, are the nastiest beasts in Africa; while most animals would not attack you unless severely provoked, a hippo would happily charge a boat just to amuse itself. The motor boats could outrun a hippo, unless it came at you from the reeds, but the guides can tell from the beast's bellowing how far away it is and whether it's in a bad mood; to the untrained ear, however, the bellows sound as if it is just behind you. Our first boat trip was in a mekoro , a traditional dugout canoe punted by the guide with a long pole, which is entirely unhippo-proof. Sound is distorted easily over water, but the hippo I was convinced had been following us as we cruised the perimeter of the camp turned out to be a toilet flushing. At night, though, the hippos come out on to the bank and wander right up to the tents - happily, unlike the baboons, they haven't figured out how to undo the catch.

Eagle Island is a bird-watcher's dream; there are fish eagles, storks, kingfishers, herons and cormorants of all colours. Perhaps the most exciting sight, though, was a baby crocodile sunning itself on the bank, immobile as a waxwork. Our guide, Tuelo, even took the boat right up to it, almost a foot from its snout, without it seeming at all troubled; but if you were to fall out of the boat, Tuelo warned, it would be on you quicker than you could blink.

Wildlife aside, one of the most impressive aspects of the Gametrackers camps was the food. We'd start with breakfast at six, before the game viewing expedition, then there would be a stop for coffee and biscuits halfway round, when the guide would find an appropriate place to stop. One of the finest was a secluded island that Tuelo took us to through a seemingly impenetrable reed bed. Later there was lunch, followed almost immediately by tea, then the evening game viewing with its break for sundowners. The evening meal was a serious affair, where all the African staff of the camp would gather to welcome the guests with traditional songs in Setswana, and dance in the communal dining room as the insects chugged and whistled towards the lights and the hippos bellowed in the distance.

The head chef for the three camps, Heather, had worked in five-star restaurants all over the world, including Princess Diana's old haunt Daphne's; we ate a lot of local fruits and vegetables, beef and fresh fish and even, on one occasion, impala steaks, which were exquisite but chafed at my conscience the next day when we came across some impala who stared at us accusingly with their big, chocolate eyes.

The final camp, Kwai River Lodge, brought the elephants back; we would sit at the bar and watch them bathing in the river, the occasional lone hippo shambling by on the far bank. Our guide took us for a night drive in search of cheetahs, who cruise through the bush with extraordinary night vision; we found fresh tracks, but no cheetahs. The drive itself was such an experience, though, we hardly minded. The landscape seems limitless in the dark, the noises magnified, the scent of grasses and sage heavier.

As we sat around the campfire on the last night, we began to question quite seriously why anyone would choose to live in London. Of course, daily life in Botswana is not quite like being at a Gametrackers Camp, which is why they don't come cheap, but if you're going to go on safari, you'll probably only do it once, so you might as well do it in style. And you will seriously start plotting ways to avoid ever going home; to my disappointment, a few thinly veiled enquiries revealed that there wasn't much call for on-site writers at the camps.

Getting there

Stephanie Merritt travelled with SAR/Southern Africa Travel (020 7627 3560). A seven-night itinerary to Johannesburg and Botswana costs from £1,825. This includes return economy flights with South African Airways to Johannesburg and Air Botswana to Maun, a night at the Westcliff, six nights all-inclusive at three Gametrackers lodges and internal light aircraft transfers

Information

See www.gametrackers.orient-express.com for information on the camps and game drives in Botswana

Flights

South African Airways (0870 747 1111) has 21 direct flights from Heathrow each week, including daily non-stop services to Johannesburg. Fares start at £570 plus taxes of £45.

It's as well, then, that the Botswana guides are so highly trained; guns are banned in the national parks, which means that the animals are less wary of humans, having never heard the sound of gunshot. It also means that your only protection is the knowledge and responses of your guide, who can read the landscape and the mood of the animals from hundreds of yards away. We had arrived in Botswana after a two-hour flight from Johannesburg to Maun, the operations centre of the Okavango Delta, where most of the country's safari industry is based. Here we were met by Gametrackers' operations manager, Malcolm, who may have been the bastard child of Indiana Jones and Crocodile Dundee - a sort of Platonic ideal of a safari guide so replete with testosterone he made the bull elephants look limp-wristed. We then transferred by light aircraft to Savute Elephant Camp, the first of the three Gametrackers lodges, but not before I'd had a screaming fit on the landing strip when the pilot began complaining of temporary blackouts brought on by his drink problem. (Yes, I know anyone else would have realised it was a joke, but I'd only had an hour's sleep. The previous night we'd stayed in the five-star Westcliff Hotel in Johannesburg, the wine was unbelievable and, more importantly, free and half the England rugby team was in the swimming pool. Well, you wouldn't have gone to bed either.) Savute is situated in the Chobe National Park, on the fringe of the Kalahari desert and - as the name suggests - is home to large herds of bull elephants during the dry season. The camp is almost as spectacular as the fauna, comprising a central dining room, lounge and bar resembling some colonial residence from the last days of the Raj, with 12 cabins charmingly (and deceptively) called 'tents'. They are, in fact, plush, thatched, air-conditioned canvas chalets with electric sockets and hot showers, and are so comfortable you could easily believe yourself in a five-star hotel room were it not for the elephants truffling about outside. I was reminded of that old joke - 'How do you know when an elephant's been in your fridge?' 'There are footprints in the butter' - on the first afternoon I woke from a nap to find a very large elephant indeed snorting about on my verandah. Okay, it wasn't actually on the verandah, but its trunk was, and we watched each other from a distance of about three feet with a guarded mutual curiosity for a few minutes until it had snuffled up all the pods from the surrounding trees and decided to lumber off. The animals are free to wander in and out of the camp, which is why you are not allowed to go outside your tent without a guide after dark, but the elephants harrumph around during the day and you just have to wait politely for them to move on before attempting to get past. Steve and June, the camp managers, showed us evidence of nocturnal visits from the local hyena - chewed cushions, a half-eaten visitors' book - and told us of the times when lions and cheetahs had been found wandering the camp at night. Fortunately we had to contend with nothing more menacing than the monkeys who, well-versed in the camp's feeding timetable, would bounce around in the rafters of the dining room, poised to swoop down and nick the food from your plate if you were foolish enough to take your eyes off it. It was winter in southern Africa, so our morning and evening game drives were fairly cold, although during the day it was hot enough to swim and sunbathe. Late rains this year meant that we were lucky enough to see herds of zebra, who would usually have migrated from the area earlier, and clusters of giraffes, elegant and melancholic, strolling by the scrubby trees that dotted the grassland. There were jackals, baboons, multi-coloured hornbills, okapi, elephants - so plentiful that our guide would simply wave a hand nonchalantly whenever we saw one and say, 'A. B. E.' (Another Big Elephant) - and, my favourites, a family of warthogs, trotting cheerfully in single file across our path like cartoon characters. In the evenings, the air was thick with the smell of wild sage and warm earth, and the evening drive would include a stop by a waterhole, where our guide would unpack a hamper of cold beers and gin and tonics, and we watched the breathtaking neon sunset, listened to the cries of the birds and vowed never to go back to London. Unfortunately it's not quite that simple. Botswana is not a place for itinerant gap-year students and jobbing back-packers. The government has decided, very wisely, to place stringent limits on the development of the tourist industry, restricting the number of lodges, and encouraging luxury safari operators such as Gametrackers/Orient Express as part of a 'high cost, low numbers' policy. This has the advantage of preserving the landscape, leaving the parks and reservations as free from human activity and close to the animals' natural habitat as possible. The following day, our gung-ho Kiwi pilot returned in the little Cessna to take us from Savute to Eagle Island Camp in the heart of the Okavango Swamp. From the plane you can watch the landscape changing beneath you, from dry grassland to pools and rivulets fringed with trees and plants; the rains had been heavy this year, and our pilot pointed out rivers which were flowing for the first time in 30 years, though my fellow passengers seemed distracted from the view when I took over the controls for a few minutes. At Eagle Island, the layout of the camp was similar, but the game-viewing was all done by boat, and the biggest danger here was not lions but hippos. Despite their plump, smiley expressions, hippos, our guide informed us, are the nastiest beasts in Africa; while most animals would not attack you unless severely provoked, a hippo would happily charge a boat just to amuse itself. The motor boats could outrun a hippo, unless it came at you from the reeds, but the guides can tell from the beast's bellowing how far away it is and whether it's in a bad mood; to the untrained ear, however, the bellows sound as if it is just behind you. Our first boat trip was in a mekoro , a traditional dugout canoe punted by the guide with a long pole, which is entirely unhippo-proof. Sound is distorted easily over water, but the hippo I was convinced had been following us as we cruised the perimeter of the camp turned out to be a toilet flushing. At night, though, the hippos come out on to the bank and wander right up to the tents - happily, unlike the baboons, they haven't figured out how to undo the catch. Eagle Island is a bird-watcher's dream; there are fish eagles, storks, kingfishers, herons and cormorants of all colours. Perhaps the most exciting sight, though, was a baby crocodile sunning itself on the bank, immobile as a waxwork. Our guide, Tuelo, even took the boat right up to it, almost a foot from its snout, without it seeming at all troubled; but if you were to fall out of the boat, Tuelo warned, it would be on you quicker than you could blink. Wildlife aside, one of the most impressive aspects of the Gametrackers camps was the food. We'd start with breakfast at six, before the game viewing expedition, then there would be a stop for coffee and biscuits halfway round, when the guide would find an appropriate place to stop. One of the finest was a secluded island that Tuelo took us to through a seemingly impenetrable reed bed. Later there was lunch, followed almost immediately by tea, then the evening game viewing with its break for sundowners. The evening meal was a serious affair, where all the African staff of the camp would gather to welcome the guests with traditional songs in Setswana, and dance in the communal dining room as the insects chugged and whistled towards the lights and the hippos bellowed in the distance. The head chef for the three camps, Heather, had worked in five-star restaurants all over the world, including Princess Diana's old haunt Daphne's; we ate a lot of local fruits and vegetables, beef and fresh fish and even, on one occasion, impala steaks, which were exquisite but chafed at my conscience the next day when we came across some impala who stared at us accusingly with their big, chocolate eyes. The final camp, Kwai River Lodge, brought the elephants back; we would sit at the bar and watch them bathing in the river, the occasional lone hippo shambling by on the far bank. Our guide took us for a night drive in search of cheetahs, who cruise through the bush with extraordinary night vision; we found fresh tracks, but no cheetahs. The drive itself was such an experience, though, we hardly minded. The landscape seems limitless in the dark, the noises magnified, the scent of grasses and sage heavier. As we sat around the campfire on the last night, we began to question quite seriously why anyone would choose to live in London. Of course, daily life in Botswana is not quite like being at a Gametrackers Camp, which is why they don't come cheap, but if you're going to go on safari, you'll probably only do it once, so you might as well do it in style. And you will seriously start plotting ways to avoid ever going home; to my disappointment, a few thinly veiled enquiries revealed that there wasn't much call for on-site writers at the camps. Getting there Stephanie Merritt travelled with SAR/Southern Africa Travel (020 7627 3560). A seven-night itinerary to Johannesburg and Botswana costs from £1,825. This includes return economy flights with South African Airways to Johannesburg and Air Botswana to Maun, a night at the Westcliff, six nights all-inclusive at three Gametrackers lodges and internal light aircraft transfers Information See www.gametrackers.orient-express.com for information on the camps and game drives in Botswana Flights South African Airways (0870 747 1111) has 21 direct flights from Heathrow each week, including daily non-stop services to Johannesburg. Fares start at £570 plus taxes of £45.

fields.headline: Coast clear for walking
fields.standfirst: Ursula Kenny finds homes fit for earls and a famous film location
fields.trailText: Ursula Kenny finds homes fit for earls and a famous film location.
fields.body:
Aberdeen, in July. Chilly, positively autumnal, in fact, and imposing - all that granite. We only went far enough in to pick up a hire car and then headed northwest to stay in a Scottish farmhouse for two days. Forty minutes later we arrived at the village of Fyvie (notable only for Fyvie Castle). Two miles on we turned off for the 200-acre Wyness family farm.

Mrs Wyness made us welcome, we never saw her husband. Not surprising really; he had this and two other farms to run. Mrs Wyness decided to offer bed and breakfast when the last of her children left home and the BSE crisis hit. She runs a tight ship. Rooms are spotless and heated (we had to have the radiators on).

We got going early the next day after porridge and making sure we were wearing lots of layers, despite the fact that the weather had 'broken' (i.e. it had stopped raining for the first time in a week). Mrs Wyness gratifyingly made much of how bad the weather was.

Our short break was divided into coastal and inland attractions - the latter being quiet countryside, rolling farmland and a very well signposted castle trail.

We headed for the coast first. Crovie is notable for being about as unspoilt as unspoilt fishing villages get. No more than a row of cottages really and so tucked in to the coastline that it is all but invisible until you're upon it. A hurricane hit Crovie in 1953 and the fishing community never recovered. Crovie is now a village of holiday homes. There is, however, no obvious concession to tourism, aside from a lookout point just above the village which discreetly offers details of local history.

The sun broke through and, bouncing off the murky Atlantic, lit Crovie up very prettily. Many happy hours could be spent exploring coastal paths and staring out to sea. Next along the coast is Pennan, a village made famous by its use as a location in the Bill Forsyth film Local Hero.

Miraculously the sun stayed out, and we headed inland to the Forest of Deer for a picnic which was lovely; we lay in the hot sun. Birdwatchers would love it here. It's not my hobby but I was stunned by a buzzard on a gate two feet from us, who took flight impressively. Red kites hovered cleverly.

After a long walk, we decided to visit Haddo House, once the seat of the Gordons and several Earls of Aberdeen. I don't know about the house (we weren't going inside anywhere once the sun had shown itself) but the grounds are quite lovely. Despite being peak season there was almost no one else around.

Our mission for the evening was to find somewhere good to eat. We drove to the Meldrum Arms Hotel in Old Meldrum. Incredibly pleasant staff served up seafood and pheasant close to closing time.

The next day we thought we should actually visit a castle and so drove to Huntly Castle, home of the Gordons and some mad earl who lived there in extravagant style in the 1400s. It was all beautifully restored and impressive, but I prefer the ruins that litter the countryside here - far more evocative and beautiful.

Fact file

Scottish Farmhouse Holidays is a central reservation service for working farms and crofts. Call 01890 751830 for a copy of its brochure. Prices for B&B start from £15 per person per night up to an average of £24 for a double room with private facilities.

British Airways flies direct between London and Aberdeen. Contact BA on 0345 222111. Prices start from £100.20 (inc taxes). Car hire can be arranged through Scottish Farmhouse Holidays.

webTitle: Feel at home in the city

fields.headline: Feel at home in the city
fields.standfirst: Serviced flats can rival hotels for luxury, says  Tamsin Blanchard
fields.trailText: Serviced flats can rival hotels for luxury, says Tamsin Blanchard.
fields.body:
'Fabulous three-bed apartment. Amazing location, within spitting distance of Buckingham Palace and the Houses of Parliament. Contemporary designer interiors. Must be seen.'

Welcome to 51 Buckingham Gate and the secret world of the serviced apartment. The long limestone-floored hallway is gently lit, with doorways at regular intervals, leading into the living room - a huge space with tasteful art on the walls and oversized, comfy sofas in shades of cream, beige and aubergine. There is a master bedroom and two others with en suite bathrooms. The kitchen is fitted out in ultra-modern stainless steel.

The apartment was designed by Noel Pierce, whose portfolio of work includes The Dorchester and the Peninsula Hotel in Hong Kong. He knows a thing or two about luxurious living. The bedlinen is made of the finest Egyptian cotton. The bathrooms are spacious, light and airy, with limestone floors and sleek Philippe Starck fittings - the sort you find in five-star hotels and fantasise about having in your own home.

But this is not a showflat for some grand new loft-style development. You are not being asked for a fat deposit to buy the place. You are simply being asked for £630 to spend the night, with as many of your closest family and friends as you like. You can cook dinner. You can even throw a party and invite everyone to stay over.

For an increasing number of travellers, hotels - even the poshest - are simply too much like, well, hotels. Some may be cosier than others. London's Covent Garden Hotel, for instance, is regularly a 'home from home' for stars, who love the fact that you can curl up with dinner in front of the fire in the upstairs lounge, topping up drinks all night from the honesty bar. Long-term guests have included Cate Blanchett, Ethan Hawke, Christina Ricci and Jessica Lange.

But for guests who are after total privacy, or simply a place where the whole family can stay without running up huge bills on room service and breakfast buffets, the Covent Garden Hotel has another option: Durley House on Sloane Street. This is where Americans such as Blaine Trump regularly book in. She treats it not so much as a hotel, but as a pied-à-terre - with maid service, private gardens, breakfast, fluffy towels and tennis courts all included. The house is decorated by co-owner, Kit Kemp, in an elegant, modern English style. There is even a piano suite which comes complete with its own baby grand, a favourite of the conductor, Zubin Mehta, when he's in town.

There are a surprising number of serviced apartments in London, ranging from the break-the-bank deluxe, to the basic and affordable. All are designed to have all the comforts of home - and add a maid, room service, and, in the case of 51 Buckingham Gate, your own butler if required.

Roy McKenzie set up in business last year, with londonservicedapartments.co.uk. He acts as an online agent, pairing up clients with their dream home - however temporary. 'I still think it's a secret, but a growing one,' he says. His list ranges from Citadine in London's Covent Garden, where a basic studio apartment for two will set you back just £102 per night (less if you stay for a week or more), to the seriously chic No 5 Maddox Street in Mayfair. No 5 calls itself 'the hotel alternative' . It has just 12 apartments, and offers guests not only a fashionably bamboo-floored Zen pad to call their own for as long as they like, but the option of 24-hour room service, a chef who will cook in your kitchen for you and your guests, personal grocery shopping, a visit from the Jet Lag clinic, and Muji bikes to cycle around the city. Prices range from £215 to £550 per night.

'The serviced apartment appeals to people at the economy end, who simply want to save on the cost of a hotel, to others who like the extra space and privacy, or the business traveller who wants to bring their family and lead a relatively normal life,' says McKenzie. He recently recommended 13 Half Moon Street in Mayfair for a film-production company in search of a traditional apartment with chandeliers. Not only is there a chandelier, there's enough room to swing on it too. And in the discreet world of the serviced apartment, no one would bat an eyelid.

51 Buckingham Gate
Luxury Suites and Apartments, London SW1 www.51-buckinghamgate.co.uk
phone 020 7769 7766.

Set in a beautiful Edwardian courtyard, the apartments were built in 1901 and recently refurbished by Noel Pierce. They are equipped with satellite TV, DVD players and luxury kitchens. Services include health spa, 24-hour room service, concierge and butler, trained by Ivor Spencer, who provides staff for Buckingham Palace. From £240 for a deluxe studio.

Durley House
115 Sloane Street, London SW1
www.firmdale.com
phone 020 7235 5537

Durley House is part of the Firmdale chain of boutique hotels owned by Kit and Tim Kemp. It offers a smart address, absolute luxury and privacy, as well as its own gardens and tennis courts. Durley House is offering special Christmas rates per night from 15 December to 15 January. One-bedroom suite £200 (usually from £250); piano suite £400 (usually from £480).

Athenaeum Hotel & Apartments
116 Piccadilly, London W1
020 7499 3464
www.athenaeumhotel.com

Next door to the grand Athenaeum Hotel in central London is a terrace of Edwardian townhouses for guests who want as little or as much hotel service as they choose. There is a twice-daily maid service and use of all the hotel facilities, including gym and spa, but, for the length of your visit at least, you can pretend that this refuge in the middle of Piccadilly is your home. Prices range from £395 per night for a studio suite, to £695 for the penthouse.

No 5 Maddox Street
Mayfair, London W1
020 7647 0200
email to no5maddoxst@living-rooms.co.uk

These apartments claim to balance 'the peace of the East with state-of-the-art technology, contemporary design and comfort'. There are just 12 apartments, and guests can cook for themselves in their own kitchens, invite a chef to do it for them, or use the 24-hour room service. For snacks and drinks, there are two mini bars, marked 'good' and 'bad' - one of which yields Yogi tea and herbal energy drinks and the other gin and Ben and Jerry's ice cream. Prices range from £215, to £385 per night.

Citadine
94-99 High Holborn, London WC1V
(central reservations, phone 020 7766 3800).

Basic, economy apartments but great central location close to Covent Garden and theatres. Prices start at £108 per night for a studio, to £159 for a four-person apartment.

13 Half Moon
Mayfair, London W1
www.no13halfmoonstreet.co.uk
Telephone 020 7409 0207

Ten traditional suites in a Georgian town house next door to the Flemings Mayfair Hotel but guests have their own entry to this 1730 listed building. The apartments all feature different decor, from High Regency to Louis XV. Prices start at £325 plus VAT per night.

Greengarden House
St Christopher's Place, London W1
020 7935 9191

Chintzy English decor. Very homely. Central location, close to Selfridges, and perfect for Christmas shopping sprees. One-bedroom suite from £175 per night.

 For a wide selection of serviced apartments in all price categories, visit www.londonservicedapartments.co.uk or www.apartmentservice.com

fields.headline: Go for it
fields.standfirst: Late bargains
fields.trailText: Bermuda | Barbados | Lanzarote
fields.body:
Holidays

Bermuda

Book by 30 November to save £150 per person on seven nights room-only at the four-star Fairmont Hamilton Princess Hotel now costing £775 between 9 January and 31 March with Bon Voyage (0800 316 0194). Children under 18 sharing pay £235. Scheduled flights from Gatwick.

Barbados

Fourteen nights room-only at the Blue Horizon Hotel, Rockley, costs £519 per person for the departure from Gatwick on 18 November. Book with Thomas Cook Direct (0870 751 9927).

Lanzarote

webTitle: Observer review: Wordsworth by Juliet Barker

fields.headline: When he was good...
fields.standfirst: Juliet Barker's sympathetic and engaging biography gives a convincing portrait of the towering figure of William Wordsworth
fields.trailText: Juliet Barker's sympathetic and engaging biography gives a convincing portrait of the towering figure of William Wordsworth
fields.body:
Wordsworth
Juliet Barker
Viking £25, pp992
Buy it at BOL

Wordsworth is a titan and it is slightly surprising that a poet of such importance hasn't attracted more biographers. He was there at the French Revolution; he knew everyone; there are fascinating, though not very soundly based tales of incest and espionage. Even given the quietness of the later life and his repudiation of most of his youthful passions, it is a terrific story.

Wordsworth's greatness is beyond argument; it was recognised in his lifetime and has never seriously been questioned since. However far you reduce the number of truly essential English poets, he is in at the last; greater even than Chaucer, Spenser, Pope or Tennyson. There is no one at that supreme level but Wordsworth and Milton.

Which in a way is odd, since no other great poet in any language wrote so much incredible rubbish. There is hardly anything in his last decades which need detain us. He had a fairly disastrous impact on English poetry, egging a lot of Victorians into a poisonous vein of the faux naif. Spenser or Pope never put a foot wrong; the worst they can be is dull or obscure. Wordsworth wrote some of the most inept poetry in the language, and yet his best work is enough to place his value beyond question.

The magic is in the simplicity. Previous generations used to laugh at some of Wordsworth's simplest things, seeing them as bathetic. But the whole magic of Wordsworth is in a simple word. His most marvellous things have an inexplicable gravity and solemnity. The 'Westminster' sonnet leaps into life at the lines: 'Silent, bare/ Ships, towers, domes, theatres, and temples lie/ Open unto the fields, and to the sky;/ All bright and glittering in the smokeless air'. The lines, so often ridiculed, about the man who says: 'I measured it from side to side/ 'Twas three feet long, and two feet wide', have a quite terrifying power; how anyone could laugh at the size of the grave of a child, set out like this, is beyond explanation.

The most famous of the 'Lucy' poems has a simple, weighty climax as far beyond criticism as the best of Blake: 'No motion has she now, no force/She neither hears nor sees;/ Rolled round in earth's diurnal course,/ With rocks, and stones, and trees'.

Simplifying the poetic language was very much what Wordsworth claimed to be doing. But, in truth, that was only part of his achievement. The ballads are as much literary constructs as the great Pindaric ode, 'Intimations of Immortality'. He retained a highly literary, even Miltonic sense of the uses of the Latinate word - diurnal or jocund. He no more invented the literary ballad than he discovered the Lake District as a picturesque destination. Even at his high period, he is a much more varied poet than his own accounts suggest, and a much more mysterious one.

The life is a fascinating and a rewarding one, though offering little in the way of scandalous bad behaviour. Any rumoured scandal tends to dissolve under scrutiny - the incestuous relationship with Dorothy seems unlikely, and the suggestion that he acted as a British government spy in France rests on a confusion of Wordsworth with another man of the same name.

But Wordsworth was still extraordinary. He was a man of unique energy, capable of walking dozens of miles in a day, enterprising enough to travel to Europe in the early 1790s and see the French Revolution at first hand. He was profoundly decent, universally generous with his time and support, and continued to be interested in absolutely anything under the sun.

Juliet Barker has written a detailed, rich and tactful biography of huge value and interest. She has delved deep, and comes up with an extraordinarily sympathetic and constantly engaging portrait. I would have welcomed a little more of a sense of Wordsworth's deep roots in eighteenth-century poetry, which here gets dismissed a little briskly, but it is difficult to argue with any conviction against a book so intricately fascinated with the period, which convinces on every page.

You feel that she understands her subject, not excusing or glossing over his occasional lapses, such as abandoning his wife, Annette Vallon, and her daughter in France, but always seeing the reasons for his behaviour.

The only blot is a disgracefully negligent index. In a book of this size and this value, one needs a bit of help, but Viking has produced an index which is useless, just a list of page numbers. The name of Dorothy Wordsworth is followed by nearly 400 separate page numbers, but if you want to know anything in particular, you will just have to fish around helplessly. I hope, before the paperback, Viking does one of our best biographers proud by producing an index worthy of a remarkable book.

fields.headline: Timeshare goes financial
fields.trailText: Like mosquitoes and diarrhoea, the timeshare salesman is a holiday irritant best avoided. However, the timeshare shark's days could soon be numbered.
fields.body:
Like mosquitoes and diarrhoea, the timeshare salesman is a holiday irritant best avoided. However, the timeshare shark's days could soon be numbered as a new and altogether more respectable player moves on to his patch - the financial adviser.

A new company claims to have reinvented timeshare as a financial services product which will be sold in much the same way as pensions and Isas. KeyWorld has teamed up with the world's biggest timeshare exchange company RCI to develop a system which enables clients to invest cash in a tax-free bond in return for lifelong savings on their holidays.

KeyWorld chief executive officer Kevin Barker explained that rather than purchasing a week in a property, clients would purchase points to redeem against holidays in a choice of 3,500 resorts and hotels worldwide. The company's portfolio includes everything from safari lodges to family villas on the Spanish costas and ski chalets in France. The minimum initial investment is £2,000 plus an annual administration fee of around £320.

'The average family spends £3,500 a year on holidays and travel. After three years you've got nothing to show for this but happy memories. Based on an initial investment of £3,000 in a KeyWorld bond the average client could expect to reclaim their original payment in holiday savings within three years and by the end of seven years they would have saved £6,400 on holidays,' said Barker.

Bonds will be sold through independent financial advisers and through KeyWorld's internet site. It is underwritten by Criterion Life Insurance, guaranteeing clients' money in the event of failure.

According to figures from RCI, the number of Britons taking timeshare holidays has doubled in the last 10 years to around 1.25m a year.
