fields.headline: Foie gras and safe sex
fields.standfirst: Robert Poulton  on the charms of Armagnac
fields.trailText: Robert Poulton on the charms of Armagnac.
fields.body:
Immaculately dressed, Christine Labatut-Joutet clambered into the small wooden pen at the rear of her farm shop, swapped her sandals for dainty white rubber boots and perched on a stool. She grabbed the nearest of seven large ducks skulking in a corner. Holding the bird between her knees, she tilted its head to straighten its neck, inserted a foot-long brass funnel, threw in a handful of wet maize - corn off the cob - and flicked a switch. A motor whirred into life, starting a screw in the funnel to deliver the maize from beak to crop without touching the sides. The duck looked undignified. We looked uncertain. Madame looked understanding.

We were in the village of Saint-Puy, in a part of agricultural south-west France which relies for economic survival on producing foie gras and Armagnac and attracting visitors to buy them. The tourist literature is heavy with hedonism. 'Prolong the pleasure,' it says. 'Taste the experience.'

Like most Brits, we had been influenced by the animal rights case against the force-feeding of ducks and geese to enlarge their livers. We were prepared to be horrified at Gallic insensitivity towards our feathered friends. But we found it impossible to cast the charming Christine in the role of Cruella de Vil. She was just so plausible.

'Ducks and geese are migrating birds and before migrating they gorge themselves with food and store it in their livers for the long journey ahead,' she lectured us. 'Farmed birds have lost the instinct for migration but they still have the same digestive system. Force-feeding does not hurt them because there is no obstruction in their necks, and they have a gizzard instead of a stomach.

'The ducks feed themselves normally in the open until they are four months old,' she said - for confirmation, we asked to see them ranging free - 'then I force-feed them with a half-kilo of maize each day for 12 days, then I kill them. In those 12 days the ducks themselves do not grow but their livers grow from 50 grammes to 500 grammes.' And then, as if to clinch her argument: 'If I didn't kill them, their livers would return to normal.'

The liver, and every other salvageable part of the duck including the gizzard and neck, is turned into pté, terrine, rillette, galantine or confit. We were invited to sample foie gras on a cracker with a local sweet white wine.

Madame was evidently sensitive to Anglo-Saxon attitudes. Before we left, she reassured us that the ducks she kept for demonstrations of force-feeding would be allowed to live. That's all right, then.

One of the best places to stay in Armagnac territory - at the risk of bumping into Terry Wogan who has bought a holiday home there - is Condom, the ancient second town of the department of Gers. It's peaceful without being too sleepy, charming without being prettified. The slightly dilapidated cathedral offers a catholic welcome to pigeons and bats as well as people.

Condom has nothing to do with a certain Dr Condom, who according to the French was the personal physician of Charles II of England and gave his name to the contraceptive sheath. Boringly, the name is a contraction of the Gallo-Roman Condatomagus. But the French are milking the coincidence for all it's worth. They have opened a shrine to the redingote (riding coat) anglaise , as they prefer to call the French letter.

The Exposition du Musée du Préservatif is billed grandly as the first step in creating an international cultural and scientific centre for contraception and the prevention of sexual disease. The more banal reality is a display of 'safe sex' publicity materials, an explanation of rubber tapping, a film promoting Durex, an engraving of Casanova 'blowing up balloons' and (while we were there) a member of the dirty mack brigade taking an excessive interest in a video on how to insert the female condom.

A comic line in postcards - marked réproduction interdite with unconscious irony - shows condoms on local landmarks including the cathedral spire.

But Condom should be enjoyed for its true qualities rather than its forced attempt at humour. These are best savoured on a warm September evening, along with a glass of Armagnac which - as the musketeer D'Artagnan, most famous son of Gers, insisted - is the best brandy in the world.

Markets, mermaids and distilleries. What to see in south-west France

 The village fortress of Larressingle with its display of replica medieval war machines and probably the only church to boast a stained-glass mermaid.

 The Gallo-Roman villa of Séviac.

 The fourteenth-century collegiate church at La Romieu, a Unesco world heritage site on the pilgrim route to Santiago de Compostela.

 The Cistercian abbey of Flaran, now an arts centre. You can reach it by boat from Condom.

 Don't miss Condom's market on Wednesdays for local produce, clothes and fabrics. Condom website: www.condom.org.

 Robert and Penny Poulton travelled with the French Holiday Service (020 7355 4747), agents for the Midi Pyrénées Comité Régional du Tourisme.

They flew Air France from Heathrow to Toulouse (fares from £163 return plus taxes), hired a car and stayed in the Hotel des Trois Lys in Condom, which charges £87 for three days/two nights half-board and £44 for each extra night.

fields.headline: Tories favour N-plants
fields.trailText: October 29 2000: Heathcoat-Amory calls for eight more nuclear power stations
fields.body:
A new generation of nuclear power stations is being mooted as a solution to serious doubts about the UK's ability to meet targets for the reduction of carbon dioxide emissions.

Conservative trade and industry spokesman David Heathcoat - Amory believes construction of up to eight new-generation pressurised water reactors - the technology used in Britain's most modern plant at Sizewell B in Suffolk - should be considered as a possible solution to Britain's energy problems.

Heathcoat-Amory, a former Energy Minister, was due to unveil the new policy at a Commons debate tomor row on the Government's public-private partnership proposals for British Nuclear Fuels.

That debate has been postponed, but Nick Gibb, junior Conservative DTI spokesman, intends to argue the case in the rescheduled debate later this month.

It will be the first time a major political party has seriously put forward the construction of nuclear power stations since the idea for a third reactor at Sizewell was abandoned in the early Nineties.

Heathcoat-Amory told The Observer : 'Taking a blinkered view of this could be cutting off one of the key solutions. There are strong grounds for considering it seriously - grounds of global warming and of security of supply. We should be seeing if nuclear is an option for the future.'

Heathcoat-Amory pointed to government figures in the DETR's Draft Climate Change Programme, which predicted carbon dioxide emissions to fall from 1990 levels - 168 million tonnes of carbon - to 152.2m in 2000, before rising to 156.3m in 2010 and 164.9m in 2020.

The document itself identifies the tailing off of the current nuclear programme as part of the problem.

Dr Helen Wallace of Greenpeace said: 'There is no place for nuclear power as a solution to climate change. Nuclear waste, accidents and the threat of proliferation are all unavoidable dangers.'

webTitle: Book of the week: Travel Photography

fields.headline: Masterclass in photography
fields.standfirst: Travel Photography - A Guide to Taking Better Pictures by Richard I'Anson (Lonely Planet, £9.99)
fields.trailText: Travel Photography - A Guide to Taking Better Pictures by Richard I'Anson
fields.body:
Richard I'Anson has contributed photographs to Lonely Planet's guidebooks for 10 years, so fittingly they commissioned him to write this guide. This is a clear and succinct technical manual to improving your travel photography - and the bulk of most amateur photographs are surely taken abroad.

The book looks at the equipment you need and basic and technical skills required to take a successful picture. It ensures you'll know how to deal with glare from snow or humid rainforest conditions and that you'll remember not to leave your footprints in the pristine desert dune you then wish to photograph.

There is basic advice on underwater and aerial photography as well as guidance on how to approach people for portraits. Much emphasis is put on planning - something casual snappers give little thought to.

However, ultimately you have to decide what you want to photograph and why. There is a tendency to think that brightly coloured Far Eastern exotica automatically makes a stunning picture. Kathmandu prayer flags, Balinese child dancers and the gnarled faces of older peasant people have rapidly become travel cliches.

The best photographs on both an amateur and professional level are those which tell an unexpected story or make the viewer genuinely curious as to what is going on in the picture. Location photography can be breathtaking but it is crucial to find an unusual viewpoint or framing device in a culture increasingly image-saturated.

The final chapter suggests how to promote and sell your work. It's worth bearing in mind that unless you have captured something truly unique or beautiful there will already be thousands of very similar commercial photographs in the marketplace.

Take the technical advice but don't forget to use your own curiosity to find what strikes you as really extraordinary. That way your photographs will have improved dramatically, even if they are never seen publicly.

There is basic advice on underwater and aerial photography as well as guidance on how to approach people for portraits. Much emphasis is put on planning - something casual snappers give little thought to. However, ultimately you have to decide what you want to photograph and why. There is a tendency to think that brightly coloured Far Eastern exotica automatically makes a stunning picture. Kathmandu prayer flags, Balinese child dancers and the gnarled faces of older peasant people have rapidly become travel cliches. The best photographs on both an amateur and professional level are those which tell an unexpected story or make the viewer genuinely curious as to what is going on in the picture. Location photography can be breathtaking but it is crucial to find an unusual viewpoint or framing device in a culture increasingly image-saturated. The final chapter suggests how to promote and sell your work. It's worth bearing in mind that unless you have captured something truly unique or beautiful there will already be thousands of very similar commercial photographs in the marketplace. Take the technical advice but don't forget to use your own curiosity to find what strikes you as really extraordinary. That way your photographs will have improved dramatically, even if they are never seen publicly.

webTitle: Nigel Lloyd  on five transformed skiing resorts

fields.headline: Favourites avoid downhill slide
fields.standfirst: Nigel Lloyd  on five resorts transforming themselves
fields.trailText: Nigel Lloyd on five resorts transforming themselves
fields.body:
Winter Park

Is this long-established Colorado resort, the closest to Denver, going to challenge Breckenridge in the British popularity stakes now that it has at last built a ski-in ski-out base village? Not only is it a fine place for beginners and excellent for intermediates, it also has plenty of challenging skiing in the Vasquez Cirque for experts. And this winter, instead of having a 20-minute hike along the Parsenn ridge to get there, it will be possible to grab a $5 tow behind snowmobiles. The coming season, its 62nd, runs from Wednesday 15 November to Sunday 22 April. I stayed in the first-rate Zephyr Mountain Lodge after it opened last March.

Zephyr Mountain Lodge, room only, two-room apartment for four people, seven nights beginning 27 January, with flights and transfers, £619. Thomson (0870 606 1470).

St Anton

There's nothing like staging a world event to give an established resort a shot in the arm. That's what has happened to this Austrian favourite, which hosts the 2001 Alpine Ski Championships for two weeks from 28 January. The railway that used to divide the village from the main slopes has been diverted. And in December a new eight-seater gondola from Nasserein up to the popular Gampen area opens, while both the Kandahar and Fang pistes have been made less forbidding. More snowmaking guns will ensure the runs to St Christoph and down the Rendl are reliable. The season runs for five months from Friday 1 December and, as I found last year, there is often excellent skiing in the weeks before Christmas. The Arlberg plastic ski pass gives access to 84 lifts, 262 pistes and 185km of downhill running.

Sporthotel half-board for seven nights starting 21 January, £590 including flights and transfers. Airtours (0800 028 8844)

La Plagne

One of the first French resorts built by skiers for skiers. There are 10 satellite villages besides the original Plagne Centre, famous for its escalator to the ski front and carpeted cable car up to Aime La Plagne. It may be at least 12 months before the lift link with neighbouring Les Arcs will be opened, creating 412km of piste and 186 lifts. But La Plagne is already making progress in other areas: the queue-prone Grande Rochette gondola cars, which over 30 years have carried 20m passengers up to some great skiing and one of the most beautiful views in the Alps, have been replaced for this season (Saturday 16 December to Sunday 22 April) by a system with 24-people cars able to lift 3,000 skiers an hour.

Plagne 1800, chalet-board for seven nights starting 6 January, £359pp sharing including flights and transfers. Ski Beat (01243 780 405)

Jackson Hole

This Wyoming mountain resort lies at the base of the spectacular Grand Tetons, which rise 1,260 metres out of the 'Hole' itself. It shook the whole concept of American skiing, when with a positively European attitude to off-piste, it opened up the backside of Rendezvous Mountain to expert skiers last winter. They can now sign out of the patrolled ski area to enjoy a further 3,000 acres of unpatrolled powder skiing. You need a guide and transceivers to enjoy it safely, and a strong pair of legs to walk back out. All this is in addition to the unpisted black Hobacks which are lift-accessed within the area. Out of 36km of piste there are plenty of runs for intermediates from the Gondola Summit, and beginners enjoy the lower, gentler Teewinot slopes. Average snowfall is more than 400in. a season. Skiing starts on 2 December and runs until 8 April. The Lodge at Jackson Hole, room and breakfast, seven nights from 6 January, £624pp sharing including flights and transfers. Neilson (08705 14 14 14)

Villars

This sunny old Swiss resort in the Vaudois Alps, once British-dominated, is rapidly smartening up its act for the twenty-first century. It has been steadily improving its lifts recently. Last season saw the installation of a six-seater up Grand Chamossaire, from just beneath the cog-rail terminus at Bretaye. The valley lift along to Les Diablerets has been modernised and this winter sees the opening of a new chairlift on the far side of Meilleret. And it benefits, too, from the new cable car up to the Diablerets Glacier. The panoramas of craggy summits are not easy to forget. There are 47 lifts serving 220km of piste, none of them too difficult and the skiing ranges from the 1,300m base village to 2,970m. The area even includes four snowboard parks.

Hotel du Golf, half-board, seven nights in January from £477 per person sharing, including Heathrow flights and transfers. Swiss Travel Service (01992 456 123)

fields.headline: Our choice
fields.trailText: Lazy adventurers | Trip lights fantastic | Grand Tour reborn
fields.body:
Lazy adventurers
A taste for adventure holidays doesn't rule out lazy days on the beach. That's the message from an expansive new 2001 brochure from Worldwide Journeys and Expeditions (020 7386 4646). The company offers trips from game drives in Africa to treks in the Himalayas. But it is also possible to add a beach holiday in the Seychelles to a safari itinerary and to temper adventure with culture. All itineraries are tailor-made.

Trip lights fantastic
The Northern Lights promise to be the best for a decade this winter. The intensity varies on an 11-year cycle of energy production from the sun which peaks between next month and March. Arctic Experience (01737 218800) offers the chance to catch the lights in Iceland. Its three-night Arctic Edge trip, based at Lake Myvatn, north of Reykjavik, costs from £495 including B&B accommodation. There are Thursday departures.

Grand Tour reborn
Some of the leading hotels in South-East Asia have united to produce a seductive Legends of Indochina brochure. It carries the diaries of two parallel 'factional' Grand Tours, one in 1902 by a young English traveller and the other taken earlier this year by her great-nephew. It is a very soft-sell for distinguished hotels such as the Oriental in Bangkok, Raffles in Singapore and Chiva Som in Hua Hin as well as the Eastern and Oriental Express which runs from Bangkok to Singapore. Brochures from 020 7805 5088 or see www.legends-of-indochina.com

Caribbean choices
The saying goes that if Columbus were to return to the Caribbean, Dominica would be the only island he would recognise. This botanist's paradise with a volcanic interior has escaped the worst ravages of tourism and has mostly family-run hotels, lodges and guest-houses. It features in a new brochure - The Alternative Caribbean - from Trips Worldwide (0117 311 4400). Haiti is featured for the bolder traveller as well as alternative looks at favourites such as Antigua, Trinidad & Tobago and the Dominican Republic.

An island home
There are just 10 rooms and four suites in Dar Dhiafa, a hotel created from four nineteenth century houses in a quiet village on the Tunisian island of Jerba. The rooms are decorated in traditional style. Wigmore Holidays (020 7836 4999) features seven nights B&B at Dar Dhiafa from £599 this winter, rising to £699 next summer, including flights from Heathrow or Gatwick.

Healthy Christmas
Walk off the Christmas calories as you go on on a festive break with Countrywide Holidays (01942 241432). These four-night 'Christmas house parties with walks' start on 23 September at six scenic British locations. The four-night stay at Stirk House Hotel in Lancashire's Ribble valley costs £299 per person including full board, an entertainments programme and daily guided walks. There is no single supplement.

Health check
From early August until 25 October, 176 cases of ebola virus infection including 64 deaths, have been reported in the Gulu district of northern Uganda. A task force has been sent to assist in containing the spread of this viral haemorrhagic fever which can kill up to 90 per cent of those infected. Signs of infection include sudden onset of fever, malaise, muscle aches, headache, followed by sore throat, vomiting, diarrhoea and a rash and haemorrhagic symptoms. The virus is transmitted through direct contact with blood or body fluids from infected people. There are currently no travel restrictions to and from the country and this outbreak poses little risk to the majority of visitors to Uganda.

To get a health brief tailored to your trip call the MASTA Travellers Health Line on 0906 8 224 100 (calls charged at 60p/min). For general travel health advice visit www.masta.org

webTitle: Brad's other car is  a flying boat

fields.headline: Brad's other car is  a flying boat
fields.standfirst: Anthony Browne  pulls on his lumberjack shirt and heads north to the one of the last wildernesses
fields.trailText: Anthony Browne pulls on his lumberjack shirt and heads north to the one of the last wildernesses
fields.body:
It doesn't take long to find the essence of Alaska. Just get off the plane at Anchorage - if you're lucky it'll be above freezing - and the first person you bump into will more likely than not be called Brad, wear a lumberjack shirt, work in oil, have a pick-up truck with twin gun racks and ask you: 'Did you know Alaska is a third the size of the lower 48 states and it's only got 600,000 people, 300,000 of them are in Anchorage?' The second question they ask is: 'Have you come for the fishing?'

Alaskans are rightly proud of their state's size. It oozes bigness. It is wild and it is empty. It has north America's highest mountain, and its last true wilderness. It has the world's most dramatic fjords with glaciers crashing into them. Before I walked from the suburbs of Anchorage up the sharp 4,500ft Wolverine Peak, the taxi driver warned me to be careful of bears. Like yeah, right by the city I thought.

'Yeah!', said the few walkers I met, all with their bear-bells tinkling away, before regaling me with stories of bear attacks in the suburbs.

Not that bears are the only problem. Last year, a man got trampled to death by a moose outside his son's school in Anchorage. It was caught on video, and, of course, it was shown repeatedly on the news. 'I thought that was a bit tasteless,' said an Alaskan called Brad on top of Wolverine Peak, Anchorage stretching out to the sea below, and endless wilderness behind.

Everything about Alaska has bigness, including the people (they have to make their bar stools especially wide). Everyone has a car but they also have two-, four-, six-seater planes. With very few roads, and such vast distances, it is the only real way to get about once you leave the cities. As you drive into Anchorage, you find a lake which is a boatplane equivalent of a car park.

Both main airports have vast areas set aside for private aircraft. That's the poor people's private planes. Anyone who is even middle income appears to have their own landing strip in their backyard. As you circle above the suburbs of Fairbanks, Alaska's second city, each house has a car on the drive and a plane on the landing strip.

Alaska is the last frontier. On the north coast, you can visit the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge. This, too, is vast, home to teeming caribou, the nearly extinct pre-historically shaggy musk ox, grizzly bears, golden eagles, moose, polar bears and snow geese.

It has been dubbed 'America's Serengeti' but, unlike the Tanzanian park, it has no roads, not even any human trails, huts, or landing strips. It is pure wilderness, as wild as it was before the advent of man. The only way you can visit it is by chartering a plane. As you weave in and out of the mountains and foothills, the pilot will find a gravel bank of a river to land on, drop you, and agree to pick you up at the same time, same place the following week.

In between, it's just you, your guide, and Mother Nature.

Alaska is famous for being cold, and rightly so. In the little village of Barrow on the north coast last year, it plunged to minus 77C (-107F). It's so cold, the tyres on cars freeze solid. The flat part in contact with the road when you park stays frozen flat as you drive off, giving a bumpy ride and a noise like 'ker-klunk, ker-klunk, ker-klunk' for 10 miles until the rubber warms up.

One Alaskan told me he didn't mind the cold: 'I look upon it as population control.' In the spring, people from the rest of the US come to Alaska, fall in love 'but by December, they're usually aching to get back,' he said.

And while it's cold, it's dark. In winter you get little or no light - but there is some compensation. Fairbanks declares itself the 'Northern Lights capital of the world', with stunning red, green, blue curtains of light dancing across the sky 220 nights a year. In the newspapers, they carry not just weather forecasts, but aurora forecasts. The dark winter also means a light summer, when days literally never end and merge one into another at the midnight sun.

I bumped into the Bishop of Alaska - he said it's the Anglican church's biggest diocese - while he commuted from church to church by plane. As the Right Rev Mark McDonald gave me a lift to the airport in his pick-up, he announced with delight that his wife had got buffalo for dinner: it made a nice change to caribou, which was their usual meat. 'How did she get that?' I asked. 'In the supermarket?' 'Possibly, though she might have shot it,' said the bishop. The Alaskans are big on hunting, but they do it for food. 'The one thing that unites the whites and the natives is disgust at the trophy hunters who come up here from Texas and shoot a moose just to cut its head off and stuff it,' said McDonald, 'It's just such a waste.'

Many of the native Americans still subsist off wild animals. The Gwich'in tribe of Athabascan Indians live off the caribou that migrate through their remote land in the far north of Alaska, as they have for the last 10,000 years.

In the community of Arctic Village, a hundred miles north of the Arctic Circle, and 100 miles from any other human habitation, the young men spend months dividing their time between hunting caribou and playing computer games. It's a haunting land of stunted trees and moss-clad tundra, encircled by hulking mountains.

Two feet down the soil is frozen all year round, forming an impenetrable layer that forces water to coalesce into endless pools, lakes, and meandering, directionless, lazy riverlets.

The log cabins of Arctic Village, its store with just a few tins in it, its wooden church, and gravel roads with no cars, have a cosy, friendly atmosphere. You can chat with the locals, whose mother tongue is now English, or walk up to the mountain. I went in surprisingly warm summer days, but a guide told me it was better to visit in winter: it's more unusual, haunting, and you have the staggering, almost endless displays of Northern Lights.

The only trouble is that with temperatures so low, your plane may get 'weathered in' and you'll spend more days in there than you planned.

Getting there

Flights from London to Anchorage start at about £450, They usually require two changes

Internal flights are available from Alaskan Airlines 00 1 800 252 7522 and also Frontier Flying Service 00 1 907 474 0014

Tours of Arctic Village are organised by Arctic Village Tours 00 1 907 479 46 48, www.arcticvillagetours.com or email the company on alaska@arcticvillagetours.com.

Trips to the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge are organised by Alaska Wilderness Journeys 00 1 907 733 4444.

Other tours are organised by Northern Alaskan Tour Company 00 1 907 474 8600 and North Star Adventures 00 1 570 297 4015 441552.

fields.headline: Videos
fields.standfirst: Of Freaks and Men | The Green Mile
fields.trailText: Of Freaks and Men | The Green Mile
fields.body:
Of Freaks and Men (1999) (18, Tartan, VHS/DVD/Retail)
The weirdest film yet by Aleksei Balabanov, cult Russian director of the Beckettian Happy Days and the violent revenge thriller Brother. Set in early twentieth-century St Petersburg, his Gogolian fable has a sinister anti-hero, a pornographer who specialises in photographs and films of flagellation, mostly involving young women and elderly female servants. He uses these images to infiltrate two bourgeois households, seeking to exploit the singing talents of Siamese twins adopted by one family and to seduce the daughter of another. This dreamlike film, banned in the Irish Republic, exudes and exults in evil.

The Green Mile (1999) (18, Warner, VH/Rental, DVD/Retail)
Like his directorial debut The Shawshank Redemption, Frank Darabont's second movie is based on a Stephen King novel. A lesser film than Shawshank, this looks at jail from the guards' point of view, and turns on the relationship between kindly warder Tom Hanks and a gentle, illiterate black (Michael Clarke Duncan) on Louisiana State Penitentiary's Death Row in 1935. The condemned innocent has miraculous healing powers (his initials are J.C.) and the impending execution is an obvious crucifixion. Though very moving, the film walks an unsteady line between the religious and the religiose.

Set in early twentieth-century St Petersburg, his Gogolian fable has a sinister anti-hero, a pornographer who specialises in photographs and films of flagellation, mostly involving young women and elderly female servants. He uses these images to infiltrate two bourgeois households, seeking to exploit the singing talents of Siamese twins adopted by one family and to seduce the daughter of another. webTitle: Long road ahead in battle against racism

fields.headline: Long road ahead in battle against racism
fields.trailText: John O'Donoghue, the Irish Justice Minister, announced the launch last Tuesday of a £4.5 million package designed to combat racism and heighten public awareness of the problem.
fields.body:
John O'Donoghue, the Irish Justice Minister, announced the launch last Tuesday of a £4.5 million package designed to combat racism and heighten public awareness of the problem.

He told the Dail that the aim of the programme would be 'to help create a more inclusive society in Ireland, where racial prejudice is effectively outlawed and cultural diversity is regarded as a strength'.

His words are likely to ring hollow with Aftab Ahmed, whose restaurant in Co Kildare was daubed recently with the words 'Leave or die'. A Pakistani married to an Irishwoman, Aftab opened his Tandoori Empire restaurant a year ago.

At first business went well but then he began receiving hoax orders for take-away meals and recently events took a more ugly turn. He has to suffer drunks from a nearby public house urinating against the restaurant and shouting abuse at his customers.

Racially motivated attacks have become all too common as Ireland tries to come to terms with its sharp rise in immigrants. Research conducted for the Irish Refugee Council shows that prejudice is also evident in encounters with the police and welfare officers.

The anti-racism package has been welcomed as an attempt to initiate a campaign of education. But groups with experience of dealing with refugees say resources over a whole range of services are needed to enable immigrants to access an equal place in society.

The number of people applying for asylum has increased sharply. It is running at 1,000 a month but only just over 500 a month are being processed. The backlog has now reached 13,000, compared with 9,000 less than a year ago.

Immigration is a relatively new problem for Irish people who, in the past, were better known for their own efforts to seek a better life abroad. The recent success of the economy has made Ireland much more attractive to people fleeing poverty and persecution in their own countries. A stroll down any street in Dublin provides evidence that Ireland is well on the way to becoming a multi-racial society but the official reaction to this challenge has been one of fear and suspicion.

The policy of dispersal - housing refugees away from large cities - has been ill-prepared. Local communities, often in small rural villages, have not been properly consulted and the resources needed for extra places in local schools and the provision of health services have been inadequate.

A recent statement from the Irish Medical Organisation highlighted the difficulties experienced by doctors, particularly GPs, when refugees arrive in their surgeries speaking no English and unable to explain their previous medical history. Some are severely traumatised and need counselling as well as medical treatment. One doctor described trying to treat a patient by telephoning an interpreter in Dublin who translated what he said to the man, and vice versa.

The reaction of local communities depends on the quality of leadership available, usually coming from the Catholic Church. Some groups provide language classes, legal advice and most importantly moral support. But there are problems that can only be solved by government. What most refugees want is to be allowed to work, but they are, for the most part, severely constrained from doing so while their applications are being processed. Trade unions and employers are united in pointing out that Ireland's successful economy is crying out for workers and that it would make sense to integrate immigrants into the workforce, rather than allow them to become a focus for popular resentment because they are perceived as 'sponging off the state.'

There has been some progress. Two equality Bills, which ban discrimination in employment and the provision of services, are now law. This month a Dublin bus driver was convicted under the Prohibition of Incitement to Hatred Act but this was the first conviction under a law which has been on the statute books for 11 years.

This was an important ruling but it also demonstrates that tough, anti-discrimination laws are of no use unless there is a political will to enforce them.

webTitle: Eriksson might seem laid-back but he's also as tough as they come

fields.headline: Eriksson might seem laid-back but he's also as tough as they come
fields.trailText: If Sven Goran Eriksson's cultured, courteous, calm and personable image makes you wonder whether he's tough enough to survive as England manager, wonder no more. The accomplished Swede hails from Torsby, an area renowned not only for producing robust cross-country skiers, but locals who are excessively headstrong.
fields.body:
If Sven Goran Eriksson's cultured, courteous, calm and personable image makes you wonder whether he's tough enough to survive as England manager, wonder no more. The accomplished Swede hails from Torsby, an area renowned not only for producing robust cross-country skiers, but locals who are excessively headstrong.

Folklore has it that when the king once inquired of a champion skier, after a particularly gruelling race, how hard it had been, he was told: 'Go and try it yourself, old fart.' While Eriksson wouldn't dream of being impolite to royalty, nor the famous old farts at Lancaster Gate, he upholds his region's tradition of resoluteness. He can definitely stand the heat.

The FA might just have found a face to fit. Yesterday they denied reports that the Lazio manager was out of the running after agreeing a new, long-term contract with the Italian club. Eriksson possesses a profound knowledge of European football, gathered while winning trophies all over the continent. He has an irreproachable character; never mind a skeleton in the cupboard, he barely has an enemy.

Glenn Hysen, the former Liverpool defender who rates Eriksson as the defining influence on his career, is unequivocal. 'I don't think there is a job that has as much pressure as the England national team but he would definitely cope,' Hysen says. 'He is under pressure every day. Lazio is the kind of club where if they don't win something every year they complain.

'The other day they lost to Verona, which was disastrous with so many big-name players, and they were slaughtered in the papers, with Sven getting his fair share too. But he waves it all off. That's the way it is, so why worry? It doesn't bother him. He's always been a very nice person, very down to earth. Still is.'

The signs that Eriksson's unshakeable self-belief would prove a huge asset were evident from his first managerial appointment, at IFK Gothenburg. He was greeted with suspicion: only 31, fresh out of university clutching a coaching certificate, and carrying no reputation from his playing days, having spent most of his time as a defensive midfield player in the equivalent of the third division with Degerfors.

Hysen remembers how it made for an awkward welcome: 'We thought it was a joke to start with because he was small, shy and very quiet. He doesn't look like a trainer really. He came from the forests up in V rmland. We were surprised the club had gone for someone like that.'

An uncomfortable start was hurdled in the composed style for which he is now acclaimed. He decided to stick to his principles and offered to stand down if others didn't want to share his vision. 'We had a meeting after six or seven games, we were bottom of the table and everyone was panicking,' recalls Hysen. 'The club was upside down. He said: "I can go if you want. We've started with a new way of playing and these things take time. If you can't be patient I can leave." We said: "No, no, no." Nobody was against him. We carried on with the same methods and suddenly everything turned around. His training and ideas were great so everybody loved him, and responded, and made Gothenburg the well-respected club it is today. We all thank him for what he did for the club, and us, when he was there.'

By the age of 34, Eriksson had guided IFK to an unexpected yet emphatic triumph in the Uefa Cup - in the process helping a clutch of players to develop from part-time to professional and international status. Eriksson's transformation was only just beginning.

He moved to Benfica, who claimed the Portuguese Championship twice in succession, before beginning a love affair with Calcio. Hysen, who followed his mentor to Fiorentina, noticed how immersing himself in Italian football and culture added further strings to Eriksson's bow. Already a sound technical teacher, he broadened his tactical horizons. The pressing game he had favoured at Gothenburg became more refined.

Personally, too, his Scandinavian reserve has been infused with a dash of Latin style and elegance, especially after his marriage to an Italian lawyer with film-star looks. At the same time Eriksson keeps his private life private, and returns once a year to the refuge of his Swedish summer house.

His life has flourished in Italy and Hysen, now a TV commentator back in Sweden, doubts he would up sticks, for England or anywhere else.

'To be honest, I don't think he'll take it. He's got it too good down there and I think he lives a perfect life in Italy. He's more relaxed, like Italians normally are. He said recently he's very flattered that everyone wants him - as coach for Sweden as well as England - but he's so Italian now in his way of life I don't think he'll take a job where he has to leave Italy. It's just my personal opinion.

'If he does take the England job I don't see why he shouldn't do well,' says Hysen. But in the end it's up to the players. If the players are not good enough - and that might be the point right now - he is not a magician. He needs the players to do a job for him on the pitch.'

That said, Eriksson's man management and motivation are the qualities that impressed Hysen most. 'The most important thing as a trainer is that he can take care of players. At big clubs like Lazio and Roma there's a group of maybe 20 good players. He has to drop six of them every game and still motivate them to go on.

'These are big stars we are talking about. He can handle that situation no problem at all just by being human, by being himself. Some managers can be very big-headed because they are in charge of a great club, but he just takes people as they are. Some managers put you aside without an explanation, but he always tells you why.

'He is very clever about handling players in different situations. He's exactly the same now as he was starting out with us in Gothenburg. We all had jobs outside of football because it was part-time, and now he has millionaire stars, and he talks to them exactly the same way as he talked to us. That's why everybody respects him.'

If Arsène Wenger was the FA's first-choice candidate, Eriksson is from the same mould. One disadvantage is his limited first-hand knowledge of English footballers, particularly those waiting in the wings. But it's not an insurmountable problem; it just needs time.

If Eriksson accepts an invitation to London he would probably bring his number two with him. Tord Grip, assistant to Tommy Svensson when Sweden finished fourth in the 1994 World Cup, is his trusted buffer, which could put Peter Taylor and Steve McClaren in a delicate position.

However, it's hard not to feel dismay over the fact that Lazio have refused the FA permission to talk to Eriksson until the end of the season. It would have been interesting to see Eriksson involved, even on a consultancy basis for England's trip to Italy - you can't help feeling he would have been in his element.

fields.headline: Paperback of the week
fields.trailText: Jan Morris puts the foundations of the modern American dream under the spotlight in this excellent biography
fields.body:
Lincoln: a Foreigner's Quest
Jan Morris
Penguin £7.99, pp224
Buy it at BOL

When Jan Morris travelled around America back in the 1950s, Abraham Lincoln was everywhere. His sober image adorned advertising bill boards as well as legal tender. The frontier values supposedly represented by the sixteenth President, such as honest hard labour, the pioneering spirit, the triumph of the common man, were celebrated in both primary-school classes and in serious biographical studies. As it turned out, the power of Lincoln as an American icon was soon to wane, but Morris was both repulsed and intrigued by the nationalist cant.

For those, like me, who visited America for the first time in the late 1980s it would not be the hang-dog features of Lincoln greeting them at airports and bus terminals, but the Technicolor grin of Ronald Reagan. Hard to imagine an American hero less like Lincoln, or an era less concerned with the value of 'honest, hard labour', yet the country was still steeped in the same defensive self-congratulation.

In Morris's personal look at the Lincoln story, she tackles the foundations of the modern American dream with just this sort of scepticism. There is no gratuitous disrespect, but humorous and disruptive comment leaps from every page. Far from venerating the kind of wise and slow-speaking Midwesterner typified by Lincoln, Morris admits they are just the sort she would least like to find herself next to on a long-haul flight.

But in the end, Lincoln himself rises untarnished, stove-pipe hat intact, from all the hogwash that is talked about him. Morris can't help both liking and admiring him and she communicates this easily, as well as giving a true picture of his background, with her naughty, breezy style. After all, Lincoln's vision of America is important, even when the reality falls down on the promise.

fields.headline: No need to be afraid.  He's a funny boy now
fields.standfirst: Once, separating Robert De Niro from his brooding, macho mystique would have been the hardest task in cinema. Now he's so loosened up, he mocks his past and is finally becoming the king of comedy.  Mark Morris reports
fields.trailText: Once, separating Robert De Niro from his brooding, macho mystique would have been the hardest task in cinema. Now he's so loosened up, he mocks his past and is finally becoming the king of comedy. Mark Morris reports.
fields.body:
It was the moustache that told you everything you needed to know. The moment you saw the thing on Rupert Pupkin's upper lip in The King Of Comedy , you knew he was a man who thought he was funny but wasn't. More than that, he was convinced of what a tragedy it would be if the world was robbed of his comic gifts. Scorsese's 1983 classic about a man who wants his shot at fame so badly he'll kidnap his idol is brilliant and funny, yet scary. At the time, people thought the film was a step back from Taxi Driver and Raging Bull. These days, it is possible to argue that The King Of Comedy tackles the same territory as Taxi Driver but more effectively. But what you never foresaw coming out of the film was that Robert De Niro would have the most financially rewarding times of his career in mainstream comedies co-starring Saturday Night Live 's comic veterans. Still less that he would one day share the screen with a cartoon squirrel and moose duo.

Nevertheless, there he is in The Adventures Of Rocky & Bullwinkle, seeking world domination as the evil, monocled Fearless Leader in the movie adaptation of a surprisingly sophisticated kids cartoon from the Sixties that is little known this side of the Atlantic. Despite the cast (Rene Russo, Jason Alexander, Billy Crystal), it seems as likely to take off over here as a Captain Pugwash film sweeping America.

Meet The Parents is a different matter. It has brought sweet relief to a movie industry that was experiencing severe autumn doldrums. The set-up is undeniably old-fashioned: a nervous young man (Ben Stiller) is trying to ask his girlfriend's intimidating father (De Niro) for her hand in marriage.

Naturally, everything goes wrong as Stiller trips himself with untruths of spiralling insanity, which isn't wise when the man you are trying to impress has a lie detector handy. Neatly assembled by Austin Powers director Jay Roach, it keeps the jokes coming fast and stays almost schmaltz-free. And it has cleaned up at the box office, securing the number one spot three weeks running and heading comfortably for the critical $100 million mark. Coming after the success of Analyze This, it means De Niro, at 57, is suddenly a bankable film star for the first time. And although he has plenty of big dramatic roles in the pipeline, De Niro has admitted he is in the market for more comedies.

That's another thing: these days, De Niro will talk the press. Not often, and when he does, he is still pretty reticent. But it is a start. At least now we know that Abbott And Costello Meet Frankenstein was a formative influence on his sense of humour. Stranger still, he is willing to do contrived magazine photo shoots. It seems he is finally unravelling the mystique he built for himself, one that backfired as the movies got worse and people decided his silence wasn't due to preserving a sense of mystery or privacy so much as truculence or plain dullness.

Both Meet The Parents and Analyze This play on the De Niro persona. Analyze This, where he plays a troubled mob boss confessing all to shrink Billy Crystal, is a more direct parody of De Niro past. Meet The Parents just needs us to know, from the moment he appears on screen, that this will be a very intense man. And so it turns out. Equally importantly, De Niro is clearly comfortable working with Billy Crystal and Ben Stiller. Considering both what sort of man and actor De Niro seemed in the late Seventies and early Eighties, his current, self-mocking attitude is an interesting development.

Dig a little deeper, and it turns out that comedy Bob predates mythical Seventies method madness De Niro. Almost unrecognisably round-faced and initially credited as Robert Denero, he got his start in a trio of films (The Wedding Party, Greetings and Hi, Mom!) directed by Brian De Palma (the idea that De Palma specialised in comedies back then is even weirder than De Niro's involvement). The first film he was in that involved the Mafia was a comedy called The Gang That Couldn't Shoot Straight, 28 years before Analyze This. That all changed when he established himself with Mean Streets and The Godfather: Part II. In the late Seventies, it would have been deemed almost insulting to ask De Niro to use his total immersion techniques for mere comedy. These days he is eager to reclaim the humourous edge to those roles. ' Taxi Driver: there's a lot of funny stuff in it. Really,' he insisted recently.

No doubt some eager film student is writing a thesis joining the dots between Abbott and Costello and Travis Bickle right now. Still, during the decade of his pomp (1973's Mean Streets to 1984's Once Upon A Time In America) De Niro appeared in nothing that could be classified as a comedy. Which made it all the more surprising when he popped up briefly in Terry Gilliam's Brazil (1985). That seemed to launch De Niro's second comedy era, which produced one fine film (Midnight Run) and a notorious turkey (We're No Angels). Midnight Run remains the most underrated film of De Niro's career: in many ways, it's the least mannered performance he has ever given and proved once and for all that De Niro could be funny. Unfortunately, it was followed by We're No Angels. The match-up of De Niro with Sean Penn (and a script by David Mamet) looked enticing on paper but turned out to be a disaster. De Niro went back to interspersing Scorsese reunions (Goodfellas, Casino) with performances in films such as Backdraft and Frankenstein that belied De Niro's reputation as the greatest actor of his generation. One exception was the unsung Mad Dog And Glory in 1993, where De Niro and the masterful Bill Murray rubbed up effectively against each other. In the Nineties, De Niro's attempts to stretch himself were mainly involved trying to show his softer side in the likes of Awakenings and Marvin's Room. But the most his work in those films ever got him was a rather automatic admiration.

It was another David Mamet script, for the political satire Wag The Dog, that refloated De Niro's comedy career. De Niro plays it straight, leaving Dustin Hoffman to indulge in unrestrained hamming. Wag The Dog still had the aura of a serious project about it. It was in Analyze This that it became clear he was committed to his comedy reinvention. The film may have been essentially lightweight, but it did the business. That De Niro produced both Rocky & Bullwinkle and Meet The Parents shows he wasn't taking on the roles just for a quick payday.

Not that he has stopped doing the serious parts. On its way to us is Flawless, a curiosity in which a bigoted security guard (De Niro) recovering from a stroke befriends a transsexual (Philip Seymour Hoffman). And there is Men Of Honor, in which a bigoted naval diving instructor learns to respect a courageous young black recruit (Cuba Gooding Jr). Whatever else De Niro has managed to come to terms with recently, quality control remains a problem.

How much De Niro has really changed recently is hard to tell, simply because we continue to know so little about him. The shift in comedy seems a sharp move, especially since the gilt came off his icon a long time ago. Not only are the bulk of films De Niro appeared in the Eighties and Nineties forgettable if not downright bad, they make you question how good he really was in the good films. That is not to say that Raging Bull isn't a great film, but that Scorsese built his movies carefully around De Niro's limitations. And the extremes of method acting probably never added anything on screen, they just made for good stories. So it is probably healthier that he now seems to regard himself as a working actor, rather than conducting a continuing experiment in changing personalities. And that he can poke fun at his own legend. Which is why De Niro himself, and not just his accountant, is probably happier now he has gone from The King Of Comedy to being the king of comedy.

Comic timing: how Bob learnt to smile

Wag the Dog (1997)

When the President is compromisingly caught with a girl scout, a ruthless spin doctor (De Niro) is called in to bury the story by whatever means including faking a war. A restrained performance from De Niro, to offset excess from Dustin Hoffman and Woody Harrelson.

Analyze This (1999)

A tormented mafia don (De Niro) attempts to unload his emotional problems on psychiatrist Billy Crystal. The problem: the psychiatrist is too terrified to listen. De Niro effectively parodies the many capi he has played, though the character is not in the Tony Soprano class.

Flawless (1999)

When ultra conservative ex-cop Walt Koontz (De Niro) ends up with paralysed vocal cords after a stroke, he is assigned to a rehabilitation programme which includes singing lessons - with the drag queen next door. Both must face up to their prejudices before they can get well.

Adventures of Rocky and Bullwinkle (2000)

When the evil trio Fearless Leader (De Niro), Boris (Jason Alexander) and Natasha (Rene Russo) cross over to the real world, intent on wreaking havoc, Rocky and Bullwinkle come out of cartoon retirement to save the world.

The moment you saw the thing on Rupert Pupkin's upper lip in The King Of Comedy , you knew he was a man who thought he was funny but wasn't. Scorsese's 1983 classic about a man who wants his shot at fame so badly he'll kidnap his idol is brilliant and funny, yet scary. These days, it is possible to argue that The King Of Comedy tackles the same territory as Taxi Driver but more effectively. Still less that he would one day share the screen with a cartoon squirrel and moose duo. Nevertheless, there he is in The Adventures Of Rocky & Bullwinkle, seeking world domination as the evil, monocled Fearless Leader in the movie adaptation of a surprisingly sophisticated kids cartoon from the Sixties that is little known this side of the Atlantic. Not often, and when he does, he is still pretty reticent. But it is a start. At least now we know that Abbott And Costello Meet Frankenstein was a formative influence on his sense of humour. fields.headline: Alan Clark Diaries read by James Clark
fields.trailText: Whatever was cut, there's still plenty to illustrate Clark's overweening vanity, his self-obsession - and his deeply uncharitable opinions of colleagues and, more disturbingly, of ordinary people...
fields.body:
Alan Clark Diaries: Into Politics
Read by James Clark
Orion Audio Books 6hrs 40mins £12.99
Buy it at BOL

Ion Trewin, the editor of these diaries from 1972-82, has selected only 20 per cent of Alan Clark's words, and the audio version contains even fewer. Inevitably we wonder what was in the remaining 80 per cent - even more narcissistic self-indulgence in the deepening lines in his face, his bad back or his losing copious amounts of money through addiction to backgammon? Or did Trewin think it wise to suppress much of Clark's most distasteful aspect - his sympathy for the Nazis and the National Front?

Whatever was cut, there's still plenty to illustrate Clark's overweening vanity, his self-obsession - and his deeply uncharitable opinions of colleagues and, more disturbingly, of ordinary people: Norman Fowler always looked 'so common'; the people in Blackpool are 'vulgar, common primitives'. However, a diarist doesn't have to be charming or likable to be interesting.

In these early diaries, Clark is on the periphery of politics, and there are fewer of the political insights which made the first volume so rewarding, but hearing his elder son read them gives the whole a human dimension.

fields.headline: Paperbacks
fields.trailText: Not a potted history so much as a sweeping overview, plus John Major, The Autobiography, A Cure for Gravity, A Closed Book and White Oleander
fields.body:
The Isles: a History
Norman Davies
Papermac £15, pp1,075
Buy it at BOL

At a time when the question of British identity is again the subject of fierce debate, Davies's history of the isles lands into the argument with a resounding thump of common sense. Beginning with Britain's geological separation from the continental mainland and ending with an assessment of our situation at the start of the new millennium, this is not a potted history so much as a sweeping overview that encompasses social, political, religious and even linguistic perspectives.

By looking at the formation and development of England, Ireland, Scotland and Wales as four distinct but interconnected countries, Davies challenges the traditional Anglocentric myths and assumptions - such as 'real' history only starting with the Roman invasion, and England being an island - that have come to be regarded as objective truths. His views on Britain's relationship with the Continent are likely to have Eurosceptics spitting, but that shouldn't put off anyone from reading a hugely impressive and relevant work.

John Major, The Autobiography
HarperCollins £9.99, pp790
Buy it at BOL

'Politics, like life, is not all black and white,' asserts John Major in his preface, and if his shades of grey have a distinctly blue tint, this is nevertheless a fascinating account of a remarkable career. From his impoverished childhood to his 1997 general election defeat after seven years as Conservative Prime Minister, Major describes the highs and lows of public life candidly and with quiet humour. His behind-the-scenes accounts of events such as Black Wednesday, Bosnia, his relationship with Margaret Thatcher and the in-fighting over Europe that nearly tore his party apart capture the drama of the period in addition to providing a rare insight to the adrenaline-rush of modern government. Compelling reading, regardless of who you voted for.

A Cure for Gravity
Joe Jackson
Anchor £6.99, pp319
Buy it at BOL

No one can accuse Joe Jackson of not paying his musical dues. By the time his big break came in 1978, the writer of songs like 'Is She Really Going Out With Him?' and 'It's Different for Girls' had already gone through the sort of musical purgatory that only stubborn obsession or sheer masochism can explain.

Clapped-out vans, badly-paid gigs for audiences of drunken sailors and skinheads and a repertoire whose high point - high point, mind - was 'The Hokey Cokey' were as much a part of his training as the three years he spent at the Royal Academy.

Joe Jackson's account of his journey from asthmatic misfit in Portsmouth to one of the leading lights of New Wave is both funny and, at times, brutally honest.

A Closed Book
Gilbert Adair
Faber & Faber £6.99, pp258
Buy it at BOL

A sightless writer hires an assistant to whom he can dictate a final book. Locked away together in an isolated cottage in the Cotswolds, a relationship built around dependency and trust soon springs up between the two men - but is the young helper as trustworthy as he seems?

By composing the novel entirely from dialogue, Adair deprives the reader of the conventional narrative details that help us 'see' what's really going on, and so forces us to sift truths and half-truths solely from the exchanges between the two central characters.

Since both of them have something to hide, the overall result is like a twisted version of Sleuth performed in the dark.

It's a neat trick, made all the more audacious when Adair finally allows us to realise the nature of the sinister game being played. A clever and original thriller that saves its nastiest surprises for the end.

White Oleander
Janet Fitch
Virago £7.99, pp390
Buy it at BOL

The oleander of the title is a beautiful but poisonous plant, an apt metaphor for the beautiful but wilful poet Ingrid Magnussen who uses its blooms to murder her lover. Her life sentence condemns her young daughter, Astrid, to a series of Californian children's homes and foster families. Told from Astrid's point of view as she's forced to adapt to a life very different from her bohemian but unstable childhood, this is essentially a story of a daughter's attempts to find her own individuality outside her mother's domineering shadow.

Some people might view the fact that it's been selected for Oprah's Book Club as more of a deterrent than a recommendation, but they shouldn't. Fitch writes superbly, creating a powerful and moving novel that has the capacity to shock as well as surprise.

webTitle: Richard Ingrams: No prizes for Cherie

fields.headline: No prizes for Cherie
fields.standfirst: Mrs Blair was back on the job weeks after giving birth... so what?
fields.trailText: The nation has been treated to another lecture on parenthood by that well-known expert, Mrs Cherie Blair, who last week was named the most popular mother in Britain by a Lloyds TSB poll.
fields.body:
The nation has been treated to another lecture on parenthood by that well-known expert, Mrs Cherie Blair, who last week was named the most popular mother in Britain by a Lloyds TSB poll.

According to Cherie, launching Parents Week, it has never been harder to be a parent, what with all the stresses and strains of the twenty-first century. Still, she insisted, being a mother was her 'most important job, both as a new one and as an old one'.

We have become so brainwashed by the feminists into believing that women must do everything possible to achieve fulfilment that few people will have stopped to consider what a bizarre claim this is. A woman who only three months after giving birth has resumed her job as a highly-paid lawyer is solemnly claiming that motherhood is the most important thing in her life. And not only is no one mocking her but she is being given a prize.

This same woman who thinks motherhood is the most important thing in her life carts her little baby around with her all over the world so that she can address the Labour Party Conference or a meeting of lawyers in New York. So devoted a mother is she that, when her teenage son is found by the police drunk and incapable in a London street, she herself is enjoying a holiday abroad on her own, having left her husband, who just happens to be the Prime Minister, in charge at home.

Plenty of women have to juggle the demands of job and family because they have to help pay the mortgage. Mrs Blair is under no such pressure. She pursues her career for other more personal reasons. That's all right by me. But don't let us let her get away with this nonsense about how being a mother is the most important thing in her life.

Travel sickness
No one has surpassed the airlines in the art of conning people into thinking they are having a good time when they are not. With the skill of professional brainwashers, they are able to turn their passengers into acquiescent zombies by playing them muzak, supplying them with hot-scented towels to wipe their faces, and lulling them with repeated suggestions that they should 'sit back, relax and enjoy the flight'.

It has taken the death of a young girl from South Wales to remind us all of the reality - that air travel is not only uncomfortable, but also unhealthy and even dangerous. Emma Christofferson collapsed and died a few minutes after getting off a Qantas flight from Sydney - a victim it is thought of Deep Vein Thrombosis brought on by sitting for several hours in the cattle-truck conditions of the aeroplane.

It is not only planes that have been designed to cram in the maximum amount of people for the maximum amount of profit. The new turbo trains now operating on the privatised railway are little different. Here too the seats allow the minimum possible leg-room with only one toilet between several hundred people, many of whom may be forced to stand.

It was one of these trains which last year was involved in the terrible crash at Ladbroke Grove. Not surprisingly it offered very little protection to its passengers in an emergency. Meanwhile, I was interested to read that the train's owners, Thames Trains, whose inexperienced driver was primarily responsible for the crash, and who operate a generally poor and unreliable service, is to be given the South Central franchise in addition, as part of a new consortium called Govia. On the railways, as elsewhere, it seems that nothing succeeds like failure.

Licence follies

You would think that a simple way to make every householder in the country better off by £104pa would appeal to politicians. So far, however, none of our political parties - not even the Monster Raving Loonies - has proposed the abolition of the TV licence.

Not only that, there was scarcely a murmur or protest at the news, confirmed last week, that as from April next year the licence is going to cost an additional £5 in order, it is said, to allow the BBC to produce more channels for the new-look digital TV.

How, it may be asked, will an extra £5 help Mr Greg Dyke to produce programmes for new channels when he is unable to provide decent programmes for the present two - even though each and every one of us is giving him £104 out of our hard-earned income to help him with his task?

How will it make any difference when, as things stand, much of our money goes on a 24-hour news service which nobody watches and a website which nobody needs, not to mention the telephone number salaries which are paid to Mr Dyke and his colleagues such as the head of sport, Mr Peter Salmon (better known for his extra-marital liaisons than the quality of his programmes), who is paid £300,000pa to broadcast non-stop snooker on BBC2.

In the absence of any lead from politicians, perhaps it is time for some of us to follow the example of the petrol protesters and mount a citizens' revolt against what is little more than a poll tax to allow Mr Dyke and his colleagues to enrich themselves at our expense. Will someone younger and fitter than myself now step forward to unfurl the banner of civil disobedience?
